Time allocation was also used at second reading and will be used, of course, at third reading. This government is very anxious to show Canadians that their word is not to be taken too seriously.

September 15, 1992
Government Orders
I want to quote the Prime Minister on August 18,1984: "Universal social programs are a sacred trust not to be tampered with". The family allowance program, instituted by this Parliament, is going to be abolished with this Bill C-80. Liberals believe this bill is flawed and the government should do the honourable thing and withdraw it.
The stated purpose of Bill C-80 is to consolidate three existing child benefits: the family allowance, the refundable child tax credit, and the non-refundable child tax credit.
Instead Bill C-80 will replace these three programs with one single monthly benefit which will begin in January 1993 if the bill receives Royal Assent. I hope it does not. This legislation means the end, as I said, to universality of family allowances.
Canadians were not consulted by this government about ending universal access to this social benefit. One can question the integrity of this government and its word and ask what is next. What is in its mind? Pensions maybe? Medicare? Who knows. Everything in this government's right-wing agenda is up for grabs and can be taken away from Canadians.
In truth this bill is an election ploy, an attempt by the Conservative government to pass off a flawed bill as a positive step toward alleviating child poverty. I want to get to that because we have reports after reports.
I have one here adopted by the Regional Municipality of Ottawa-Carleton and addressed to the Prime Minister dated August 31,1992. It states: "One in six Canadian children lives in poverty, poor children experience a 50 per cent higher death rate from all causes, health conditions for our aboriginal children in Canada have been compared to those of the Third World, and their average life expectancy is eight years lower than the national average".
Suicide is the second leading cause of death among Canadian adolescents. The high school dropout rate, which averages about 27 per cent across Canada, is over 90 per cent in some areas and among some groups of young people. This is disastrous record. An estimated one in four girls and one in ten boys is a victim of sexual abuse. It goes on and on and on.
There is no child policy with this government. There is absolutely no heart for the problems that are at this time striking our youth, our young people.
I do not have much time so I will just relate some of the problems with Bill C-80. For example, the government says these changes will increase assistance for children over the next five years by $2.5 billion. Nonsense. One should ask how much child benefits would have grown without these changes. Between 1986-87 and 1990-91, family allowance payments grew by $275 million and refundable child tax credits by $750 million. This is smoke and mirrors.
The new child tax benefit will be based on family income as reported in income tax. This means it could take 12 to 18 months for the amount to change to respond to possibly dramatic changes in family income. This could present a serious problem for some families.
Third, the government conveniently forgets to mention that through partial indexation the Tories already took $3.5 billion out of the child benefit system between 1986 and 1991. In five years $3.5 billion has been cut from family benefits. The benefit is indexed only for the part of inflation exceeding 3 per cent. What will the government do to ensure that the value of the child tax benefit does not erode through further inflation? Nothing. It is heartless.
For women who receive low salaries or work part time, this bill means that after paying their work expenses and day care that they will probably make more money staying home. This type of incentive is a step backward from the right of women to work and to economic independence.
These measures in Bill C-80 offer veiy little to middle class families. A two-earner family with an annual income of between $30,000 and $40,000 will receive additional benefits of less than $4 a month. With inflation at 3 per cent a year, this benefit will disappear within a year.
Canada's poorest families who are on social assistance will receive absolutely no benefit from this measure. There are 2.5 million Canadians now on social assistance.
Furthermore, C-80 is far from being adequate compensation for the government's callous abandonment of its promise for a national day care program. Where is that program which was promised in the last election? That is another one of those commitments that was not kept by this government.
September 15, 1992

Let me quote the reaction of various groups to the new child tax benefit act, Bill C-80. Gerard Kennedy of the Canadian Association of Food Banks called it "the most deceptive and cruel thing coming from government that we have seen in a long time. It is a tremendous blow to the hopes of low income people". Sue Wolstenholme of the Canadian Day Care Advocacy Association states: "Either the federal government still does not grasp the problems of child poverty or child care which Canadian families face or they really do believe that they can trick the public with yet another illusionary tactic".
The government is admittedly and deservedly ashamed of Bill C-80. It wants it passed through this House so quickly that it imposes limits on debate so that people will not get the benefit of understanding this bill, of studying this bill and taking it for what it is worth, absolutely nothing.
The government has forced this bill through the House at second reading, imposed closure and forced it through committee and has forced it through report stage today and tomorrow to get the bill. Why? It is because it is ashamed of this bill. It should be ashamed of this bill.
The government knows that this bill does not address the vast problem of child poverty in this country.
Tory economic mismanagement with unemployment now up to 11.6 per cent has resulted in thousands of individual Canadians being in difficult situations financially and otherwise.
At one time it seemed that the government would take the problem of child poverty seriously. In 1989, remember, the government gave its support to a motion calling for the elimination of child poverty in Canada by the year 2000. Instead, the number of children living in poverty has increased. In 1989 there were 863,000 poor children in Canada. In 1990, one year after, the figure was
1,013,000.	That is a jump of 150,000 in a year. We can safely assume that these numbers increased throughout 1991 and into 1992, with layoffs continuing as they are in this country.
Mr. Speaker, you have indicated to me that my time is up. I will just read one last quote from the columnist Leonard Shifrin. This is what Mr. Shifrin had to say: "If there was a Pulitzer Prize for flim-flam, the Tory snow job masquerading as a budget white paper would win
Government Orders
hands down. Despite what it seems to say, basic benefits are not really being raised for the poorest families".
In my riding of Ottawa-Vanier there are poor children, there are poor women, there are poor people and yet this government in this measure of Bill C-80 is showing absolutely no sensitivity. It has no heart. We will vote against this bill and fight this legislation.

Mr. Speaker, this is quite a sad day in the House of Commons as far as I am concerned. I have seen a number of sad days in this House since my election in 1988. Those sad days include many budget days when this government has dealt with programs that affect the quality of life of people in my constituency and across Canada in a very negative way. I have seen days when the government has taken steps to actually remove benefits that Canadians have come to count on to ensure that their businesses, their families and their country can survive.
This day is one that I never thought I would see either as an ordinary Canadian citizen or as a member of this House elected to represent the interests of the people of The Battlefords-Meadow Lake in northwest Saskatchewan.
Here we have a situation where this Bill C-80 will remove the family allowance benefit that has served Canadians since the mid-1940s, nearly half a century, and is now providing some $2 billion of assistance, primarily for families with children. The Canadian people are probably going to get a surprise in January because of this program.
I want to make very it very clear here today that I do not support Bill C-80. I do not support the removal of the family allowance program. I do not support the action the government is taking today to railroad the bill that eliminates the family allowance program through this House.
I know that in January my office will be receiving hundreds of phone calls from Canadians living in The Battlefords-Meadow Lake constituency, wanting to know where their family allowance cheque is for that month.
This summer the government railroaded Bill C-80 through committee stage. It ran this through so quickly that many groups that wanted to speak to it were unable

September 15, 1992
Government Orders
to do so. Those that did speak, spoke strongly against the inclusion of many of the arguments in Bill C-80.
Today we have just gone through a motion to limit the speaking time on this bill, all in an effort to deal with this matter while the country is locked in a debate over the national referendum. If there was any way this government could have orchestrated a clean way of dealing with this bill without subjecting itself to a tremendous amount of opposition from across this country, it has found it in dealing with it this week in the House of Commons.
This is not a bill that will address child poverty, as the government says. We all recognize that one in six children in this country are living in poverty. It is a deplorable situation for young children and youth throughout Canada. It is a comment on the government's economic agenda that has been in place since this government's first election in 1984, an agenda that began with the previous government and the previous government's attack on some of the social programs.
More important, what is happening here is that we are creating a situation whereby we are sustaining the stereotype Canadians have about this place, this institution and about parliamentarians.
When governments take action such as this government is taking on the family allowance bill, railroading it through during the summer and during a period of time when Canadians' attention is diverted elsewhere, it is to sustain the public's perception that this place cannot be trusted, that politicians, Parliament and government are doing things that will jeopardize the ordinary Canadian's ability to survive the daily rigours out there in the countryside. I have known this from conversations with my constituents for most of the last couple of years. It is a process of distrust that began quite some time ago and has continued through this government's use of bringing in the GST, the goods and services tax, at a time when the Canadian people were saying they did not want these additional taxes. The Canadian public has responded by reducing spending in this country and throwing tourism, small business and manufacturing into jeopardy because consumer spending is not there.
People are not prepared to provide any more taxes to this government and they feel the whole tax system is a threat to their ability to earn income and to provide for their families. We see this fear that Canadians have
about the security of their income as they respond to matters that relate to pension income, income that is earned in the workplace, the declining value of the dollar that is earned in the workplace, the increasing costs of going to school and providing education for young people, the poor response of governments to crises in the fishery, in agriculture, in the mining and processing sectors and, most recently, the determination of this government to sell the North American free trade agreement to all of us at a time when we are saying that the free trade agreement with the United States has failed us. The government is simply creating one situation after another in which the Canadian people's response is they do not like what this government is doing, they do not trust this government and therefore they do not trust the institution of Parliament or any of those people who are working within that institution.
It is a threat not only to the well-being of Canadians but to the well-being of this institution which we must rely on for generations to come because we live in a democratic system, a system in which we understand the value of representation for the well-being of Canadians. When we throw that system into jeopardy, we are throwing into jeopardy our ability to respond in times of crisis and even in good times for Canadians.
I remember back in 1944 when the Saskatchewan people radically changed the face of this country by voting for and supporting the first socialist government in North America. Tommy Douglas was elected in Saskatchewan to lead that particular government. One of the things that guided Tommy through his years as premier and much of the philosophy of this party was his belief that people do not need governments in good times but they need governments in bad times. What governments do when times are good is prepare for the bad times so that we can sustain and rebuild a breaking and deteriorating economy and programs.
What is happening here is we have a government that did not provide that safety net during the good times. We have had some good times in this country, at the beginning of this government's term in office. Nothing was put away. We built debts and now we are trying to find ways to eliminate those debts by reducing the things that this country needs so desperately during the tough times. Canadians do need government in tough times. We need it in the fishery, we need it in the farming sector. Canadian families need the government during
September 15, 1992

the tough times to support them when they cannot support themselves.
The elimination of the family allowance, the elimination of the tax deduction that is part of this bill and the replacement of it with a program that does not make a whole lot of sense to me or to any of the witnesses who appeared at the committee stage are simply more indications that this government is not prepared to be there to help Canadians during the tough times.

Mr. Speaker, I want to go on record with respect to this bill and some of its amendments because I believe this is a critical piece of legislation that is being rammed through at a time when we are not being given the opportunity to explain it adequately to Canadians.
Some of you will recall this quote: "Universal social programs are a sacred trust not to be tampered with". That was made by Brian Mulroney on August 18, 1984.
It is rather interesting. Clearly universality is no longer a sacred trust. I suspect the Prime Minister would be saying he is not tampering with them.

"I am crushing them and eliminating them altogether." So in a way, he is right.

He is not tampering with them anymore. He is eliminating them.
People are upset that roughly eight years ago that statement was made and eight years later it is a complete reversal.
There is another thing that is upsetting Canadians with respect to this.

Mr. Speaker, did you know that time allocation has been imposed 39 times since this government came to power in 1984, and closure 21 times? The government has tried to restrict debate a total of 60 times on key legislation, key issues, questions that are important to Canadians. If we look at the history of the Parliament of Canada, it seems that previously this happened a total of only 10 times, compared with 60 times under this
Government Orders
government. These attempts to restrict the speaking time of members in this House are absolutely incredible.

The other thing that is bothering Canadians is that they see this, although the government has been able to fool some of them as an election ploy. There are time limitations imposed on the debate. We are being prevented from discussing this.
There were a few public hearings during the heat of the summer months. They were limited as well. The government is passing this legislation at a time when people are preoccupied with two major questions: the unity of this country and economic questions that we have never seen before; questions of unemployment, questions of social assistance, questions of food banks, questions of bankruptcies. During that period of time the government is trying to get this legislation through.
Hopefully, with the few minutes we have available to each and every one of us who wants to speak against this bill, we can explain to Canadians what is happening. There has been $3.5 billion taken out of support to Canadian families and $400 million put in. Clearly, that is not fair.
Families living on welfare will not get one penny more. I find that unfortunate because surely they are the families that need the most assistance. There will be one million families that will be net losers. The working poor will get, according to the estimates that were given to me, roughly $42 a month. It was the Minister of National Health and Welfare who said that is was better than nothing.
Yes, it is a little better than nothing but surely it is inadequate because it does not address the needs of children who are living in poverty. It does not recognize that if we do not meet that challenge today, we will have to come to grips with it later at a much higher cost in terms of crime, unemployment, social assistance and frustrations on the part of those Canadians who will feel that they were not given the opportunity to live and grow up in a kind of atmosphere that they could have contributed fully to Canadian society.
There is another disturbing element to this. The old family allowances program is now gone forever.

Government Orders
The new program will be starting at the beginning of the next year. For a period of time, a few months, there will be additional moneys made available but they are not really additional moneys.
That is made to entice Canadians, to make them believe that there is something here that there is not. Why was it done? Clearly, to try to get re-elected. I find this shocking. I find this so misleading that it angers me as it angers a number of Canadians.
I can well imagine that there was another telephone conversation on this item that went something like this:

"We should limit debate. We should make sure public hearings are held in the summer. We should be absolutely sure this bill is adopted when people are distracted by other priorities such as the Constitution, the referendum and economic issues".

If there was a call made, and there was, with respect to what the strategy would be with the North American free trade agreement, trying to discredit people who would oppose it, clearly there were discussions as to how this particular bill would be pushed, rushed and rammed through Parliament.
It is unfortunate that this is happening because it discredits the government in its efforts to attempt, for example, to bring about a sort of constitutional renewal and to have the question decided with some sort of finality in a positive sense with the referendum.
Some people may ask that since I am from the opposition, what could I say that is anything but negative.
I applaud the fact that there are going to be fewer programs because I think there is too much complexity out there.
However, let us not lose sight of the fact that because we made that little bit of inroad on that point it does not address the major question. The major question is what are the needs of Canadian children and Canadian youth? My colleagues have given some of the statistics. I will not repeat them but let me say what third party people are saying about this agreement.
Ken Battle from the Caledon Social Policy Institute said:
The federal government proposal to change child benefits is seriously flawed-(the proposal) does little in the short term and virtually nothing over the long term to make a dent in child poverty-Clearly this is a pre-election reform -
Sam Snobelen from the End Legislated Poverty said:
lo us it is clear the so-called "child benefit" will be a detriment to the entire country, especially to children, and eventually to seniors.
Joan Smallwood, minister of social services in B.C., said:
The new benefit is not simple, not fair and not generous.
There is a whole lot more. Professor Shelly Phipps of Dalhousie University points out one of the major flaws that we have not talked sufficiently about:
Suppose someone experiences a drop in income in January of a year, say 1993. Then they won't file an income tax return until April 1994. But we won't find out that they became poor in January 1993, and as I understand the proposal, they won't receive any child benefits at all until July 1994. So in this extreme case they could be waiting as much as a year and a half-
Citizens for Public Justice said:
By withdrawing or failing to provide the kind of supports that families need to move out of poverty, the federal government's attempt to alleviate child poverty through the child tax benefit will be ineffective.
The Social Planning Council of Metropolitan Toronto and the Child Poverty Action Group ask why fiscal restraint must come at the expense of families with children.
Lise Corbeil from the National anti-Poverty Organization says:
We believe that Bill C-80 is flawed and dangerous - we therefore ask your committee to recommend rejection-
She points out that $3.5 billion was siphoned away from child benefit programs and $400 million is being put in.
Trevor Williams, Family Services Canada, says:
-without indexation this program will continue to slip year after year.
Terrence Hunsley points out that it is flawed. Martha Friendly makes the same point that we are going toward the United States' system as opposed to the European system. Dr. Robert Glossop of the Vanier Institute of the Family criticizes the proposal.
September 15, 1992

Marcelle Dolment says:
The Network finds it inconceivable that a government no longer wishes to recognize either the family responsibilities parents assume or their investment in the country, in the human capital that children constitute.

I have made it clear that this bill does not meet the needs of people who live in poverty. It is just an election ploy, and I am not quoting myself but what people who made a thorough study of these proposals have said quite clearly.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased today to speak in favour of the motion of my colleague from Winnipeg North Centre.
I also want to commend my colleague on the leadership that he has provided in opposing this legislation. As we know Bill C-80 will create a monthly payment for our child benefit program. It is going to take the family allowance and the child tax credit and they are going to be combined into one.
My party and I have a lot of objections to this legislation. This morning, due to the limited time, I will only be able to touch on probably two or three of these.
First I want to say that this government has made a mockery of the whole legislative process with this legislation. What it has been trying to do ever since it was introduced is get this legislation through.
There has been a lot of objection to this legislation, not only from the opposition parties but from groups and individuals all across this country. Certainly, the government should have got the message when in the standing committee, every group and witness who appeared, except one, were opposed to this legislation. There were a lot of groups and individuals that the government did not even give the opportunity to appear before the committee and speak on this very important legislation, which will bring about profound changes in this area.
The Conservative government controls the committee and it, as I mentioned, allowed interest groups very little time to prepare. When they requested more time to prepare to appear before this committee they were refused. The government cut off the number of individuals in groups who could appear before the committee.
Government Orders
After the presentations had been made they only allowed one hour of discussion on this important legislation. It really makes one wonder whether the government is really interested in hearing from groups and individuals, whether it is really interested in getting constructive and positive input into this legislation that we have before us. I know that the Canadian people expect better than this from the government, especially when it comes to an issue and a concern that is as serious and important as children's future.
Of course we have had glossy brochures that have been put out by the government on this. They say, and I want to quote: "-our future well-being and prosperity depend on our children".
Certainly, I agree with that. Unfortunately, with this program the government is really not looking after the needs of youth and children.
It took the government eight weeks from the time this program was announced to actually get it into legislation. Yet, the government only gave the committee studying this legislation eight days to hear from witnesses and groups interested in stating their views and in debating the bill. I am told that there were 10 social groups that asked the government for a little more time to prepare their briefs, and the government absolutely refused. I think that is very unfair. These social and interest groups in this particular area deserved to be heard. They have a lot to offer, a lot of constructive, good input to make on this legislation. However, obviously the government is not interested in hearing how this legislation could be improved or how this House of Commons could bring in a program that would better meet the needs of our children and our youth.
Across this country social groups-people who are involved in this area, are experienced in it and have the expertise and that know-have been very critical of this entire package and they have been critical of the government for not giving them adequate time and opportunity to study and debate this legislation. That is very unfortunate.
I served as minister of health and social services in Prince Edward Island and I always found that social groups and interest groups in this area had a lot to offer.

September 15, 1992
Government Orders
I believe the government has been very unfair in saying no to these people.
I want to quote the executive director of the Canadian Council on Social Development. This legislation will introduce "some of the most profound changes to Canada's income security system that have been contemplated in recent years-As a result, they require far more serious and broad debate and discussion than a surprise two-week process in Ottawa would allow".
I feel that the government has been very unfair and I have stated why. I am not the only one I just quoted the executive director of the Canadian Council on Social Development.
Another group that has not really been adequately consulted is the provinces. This is despite the fact that 11 first ministers agreed in March of this year to form a partnership to work together on income security issues.
Despite that agreement, the federal government is just charging right ahead. It is paying lip service to this arrangement, but certainly there are a number of provinces that are opposed to this legislation and the government is really not listening.
I have a lot of other points I want to make on this subject. Mr. Speaker, I know you are signalling me that my time is up. Maybe later on third reading I will be able to put my other concerns about this legislation on record.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretai^ to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to participate at report stage. I would like to comment on some of the amendments.
Listening to the debate I cannot help but be amazed by the perspective shared by some of my colleagues opposite who think that our society is frozen in time and that nothing is ever supposed to change, when in fact society is constantly changing. The dynamics-especially in the 1990s it is so obvious the way the world is changing. There are all kinds of things changing, yet it seems that social programs in Canada, rather than being responsive to the needs of Canadians, are supposed to be static, frozen in time and never change.
I find that rather an interesting concept because I really think that it is dissonant with reality. I just put that forward as a general observation.
I listened with great interest to my hon. friend for Malpeque who served with great distinction as minister of health in Prince Edward Island. I was waiting to hear some of her substantive points but I found she spent most of her debating time discussing the amount of debating time that was available instead of getting on with it. I would have liked to have heard more of her substantive comments on the bill.
However, that being as it is, I have to say that it is my impression from the constituents that I represent and from what people tell me in Nova Scotia that one of their greatest demands of government today is that it use whatever money it takes in taxes efficiently and wisely and in the most expeditious manner.
I find it hard to believe that my hon. friends opposite continue to be mired in the belief that people like J. D. Irving need family allowance for their grandchildren. He is one of the people who is supposedly going to be hurt by this bill because he will no longer have family allowance for his grandchildren. When Eric Lindros gets married and has children they will probably not qualify.
My friends opposite think this is a heinous, villainous and Draconian thing. With respect, I do not think that is the case. I think that the demand and the expectation of Canadians is that those dollars will be used for the benefit of those Canadians and those Canadian families who need them. That is precisely the purpose of Bill C-80 and that is precisely why this change was so positively greeted by the Canadian public when it was announced in the budget last February.
All this talk about the sacrosanct nature of universality is just so much hog-wash and is not really relevant. The important thing is that programs respond to the needs of the times and that programs exist to support the people who need that assistance.
One of the things that has amazed me during my short tenure in this place to date is the fact that one is not obligated to speak the truth but one is not permitted to call another member to account for failing to speak the truth. Of course, I will cast no aspersions, but I must make reference to the fact that a number of members have talked about $3.5 billion being allegedly taken out
September 15, 1992

of the system through partial de-indexing. That is an extraordinarily misleading piece of information.
It is most regrettable that members would throw out a figure like that, which is certainly at odds with the truth and certainly ignores the fact that up to now since this government has been in it has increased the refundable child tax credit four times and has also introduced a supplement of $213 for children under seven when the child care expenses have not been claimed. Therefore, that figure is extraordinarily erroneous and would certainly mislead anybody who did not have an opportunity, as I have just provided, to become familiar with the facts of the situation.
I would also point out that Bill C-80 is going to increase child assistance by $2.1 billion over the next five years, and 80 per cent of those funds-
And not one cent for the poor.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
-and those funds will go to 80 per cent of the families, the families with the low income. With all due respect to my hon. friend, he is absolutely incorrect. The low income Canadians will be the principal beneficiaries and will end up receiving more money as a result of this measure. That is why the government has introduced it and that is why it is going to be welcomed, as it has been, by Canadians.
Similarly, Motion No. 25 calls for the elimination of the earned income supplement. That is not a complicated issue at all. The intent here is that it is the belief of this government, a belief obviously not shared by some of my friends opposite and I know not shared by the current Government of Ontario, that there should be incentives and encouragement and that nobody should be disadvantaged for trying to get out of the rut of welfare and back into employment. The intent of the earned income supplement is to ensure that there is no loss of income for somebody who does return to the work force and wishes to move ahead in life.
Indeed, my hon. friend from Ottawa-Vanier made reference to the fact that single women would be disadvantaged when returning to the work force. I
Government Orders
believe he said they were single mothers. The point remains that the earned income supplement addresses this problem specifically and assists people to move back.
Moving back into the work force not only affects one's income, it affects one's self-esteem, sense of productivity and a lot of other things. I think our social safety net should be there to assist people but at the same time it should provide encouragement and opportunity for people to become productive members of Canadian society.
In conclusion, I think that it is important that the facts of this bill be known. It adds $2.1 billion to federal child benefits over the next five years. More than 80 per cent of Canadian families will receive these benefits. Two-thirds of all the families in Canada, 2.4 million families, will receive higher benefits. They are targeted at lower-income families. The system is going to be responsive. It has been well received by the Canadian public.
I respectfully suggest that my hon. friends opposite take their heads out of the sand and listen to what the Canadian people are saying. They will welcome this progressive measure that has been introduced by this progressive government.

Mr. Speaker, those previous comments almost leave me speechless, but they certainly beg some sort of appropriate, sensible, rational and compassionate response to that kind of nonsense.
Hard times have demonstrated how easily we sacrifice the care of the young, the old, the sick and the helpless. The fragile state of social order and tolerance cannot withstand the pressures of mass unemployment and growing economic disparity. The smug assumptions of our peaceable kingdom depend more on recent prosperity than on our long-term history.
I think this government is out there polling each and every day. It does not tell us the results but it is out there polling. I think it finds out that it is fashionable and almost popular to do this sort of thing. It can attack the watershed of social policy in this country and get away with it because times are tough. Where does one go when times are tough? One picks on those people least able to respond in any sort of organized fashion. The bill is cynical and the timing is even more cynical.

September 15, 1992
Government Orders
I am reminded of Christmas in 1989 when the last watershed was breached. That was the initial attack on universality in this country. It was the clawback provision. It was done for Christmas. It was a Christmas present for seniors and families that received family allowances across this country. There was a great desire to get it done quickly.
Here we are now sitting and discussing a referendum bill in Parliament that the government wants urgently to get through. Why, Mr. Speaker? It is because it is extremely unpopular despite what the polls say.
Our social safety net includes unemployment insurance, universal old age pensions, maybe someday a national day care program and also, in this hostile climate, family allowances. It is the product of many factors: our history and heritage and our need to huddle together against the cold. We are a scattered people who are thinly spread across a forbidding landscape. There are not enough of us to entice private capital to establish the institutions that in other societies define a nation and tie it together. Instead, we have used public capital.
Canadians are noted for what they have. The longer this government is in power we will be noted for what we had. If one was going to target a group, one would think that one would not target the poorest of the poor. One would think that one would not compare one level of poverty with another level of poverty. One would think that if one was going to target a group to assist the lower levels on the economic scale that one would attack the wealthiest of the people in the country to access the riches. Canada is a country that now is regarded as having one of the highest concentrations of wealth in the world. It does not seem believable, but statistics prove that in fact it is. More and more wealth is in the hands of fewer and fewer people.
We talk about priorities a great deal in Parliament. We talk about $4 billion helicopters that we may or may not be able to land, but that perhaps is not the issue at this point in time. Surely, the allocation of funds could be more appropriately allocated than with this kind of decision making.
There's the cap on CAP for the so-called wealthiest provinces: Ontario, British Columbia and Alberta. That accounts for 29 per cent of the debt accrued by the
Ontario government. We are criticized for caring and for responding to the needs of those people, but we are all having to pay. The federal government is washing its hands of social programs in this country. They are eroding them.
There was a discussion or a consultation paper in January 1985.1 know this government was around at that time. It said that the concept of universality is a keystone of our social safety net. Its integrity must not and will not be called into question.
I appreciate that times have changed and there are dramatic things happening around the world and in this country. However, if something is a cornerstone it is a cornerstone. It is not something to peck away at or take away from so gradually that people may not understand. That leads me to the simplicity. It says it wants to simplify the system. I defy you to read the government brochure on the child benefit and attempt to understand it. It is nearly impossible. It is not simplistic, Mr. Speaker.
The government is going to spend $500,000 to inform Canadians as to what it is doing. I suspect it would be better spent on the people who require these funds. It is spending $1.8 million on the NAFTA agreement. This is ironic at best and tragic at worst.
When one pits group against group, even though not intentionally, the middle class may look at this and say it does not have any great inclination to involve itself in this debate at this point in time. However, they shall soon be affected. It is like the clawback provision. Since it is not indexed to inflation, sooner or later we will all get caught and it will be too late to turn back.
This is a watershed and a most unfortunate one. It is most unfortunate that it is being debated at a time when the very future of the country is at stake. It would otherwise receive much more attention from everyone, especially those most affected by this particular bill.
I am fearful that the government's course is one of Thatcherism, Reagan's economics, or, worse still, similar to that of the governor of Michigan, John Engler. He made a campaign promise and he followed through. One day he said that he would cut everybody including all single parents. There would be no more social assistance.

Immediately in the city of Flint, 83,000 people were put on the streets. Governor Engler said get a job but anyone who knows anything about Flint, Bay City and Saginaw, Michigan, there are no jobs. People are living on the streets. They are dying on the streets.
Under Mr. Engler's scheme, under the guise of saving money, the people's safety net probably will not be a money saver. He pulls a study of Mr. Hollister pointing out research that shows if 5 per cent of those who are cut off end up in prison, another 5 per cent end up in mental institutions, the state will pay out more than it saves.
Cutting people off was not an economic decision, it was an ideological decision. I believe that is why this government acts in the way it does. It is more ideology than good sound economic sense, especially for those among us who can least afford this kind of backward legislation.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to join in this debate and I am angry, frustrated and disgusted.
Today I listened to my hon. colleague and fellow Nova Scotian from the South Shore and earlier I listened to comments by the hon. Minister of Veterans Affairs. I realized that both of these hon. gentlemen have the wrong end of the stick in this whole debate.
They both made allusions, one in a speech and one just in a comment earlier, to wealthy people. They both used the same family which happens to be one of the wealthiest families in our region of the Atlantic. Should those people or should their children be getting the family allowance?
It first of all shows a total misunderstanding or lack of understanding of the principle of universality and why the principle of universality is a good one, but I am not going to get into that at the moment. It also shows a misunderstanding of the way the family allowance in particular has worked.
There has been so little time for this debate. One is reminded of the quote from MacBeth about the murder of Duncan: "If it were done when 'tis done, then 'twere well it were done quickly". This is the murder of the principle of universality. It obviously falls into the same category.
Government Orders
One of the things that has been missing in this debate is the question of the women who receive the family allowance to use for their children. I have gone to a number of meetings over the past several years with colleagues from the New Democratic Party and the Conservative Party, with women's groups representing women who stay at home. The Conservative Party in particular has always been a great champion, allegedly, of women who stay at home.
I am talking about the fact that if we are going to have universal accessible child care, for example, we must do something at the same time for women who stay at home, et cetera. Those of us who worry about the social programs affecting women in the work place, the economic programs, are somehow forgetting about women who stay at home. That has been a charge that certainly has been levelled at me and at other women on this side of the House by women and men as well on that side of the House.
It is time to turn the glass on this legislation in that context. I would ask my hon. colleague and friend from the South Shore and his other colleagues to think about this. I see the minister is no longer with us.
Some years ago a challenge to the universality of family allowances mounted in my own party. This was before I became a member of Parliament. I am happy to say that under the combined championing of the hon. Monique Begin, the hon. Celine Hervieux-Payette, the then senator Loma Marsden and a number of women in the Liberal Party, we beat down that challenge to universality. Would that our colleagues on the other side of the House had had the same luck.
One of the things I learned in that battle some nine to ten years ago was what the family allowance cheque means to an awful lot of women in this country. It does not just mean something to single mothers or low-income women. It means something to women who live in the Rockcliffes, the Rosedales and the south ends. It means something to the women who live in Shaughnessy and British properties. It means something to the women in Westmount. In other words, it means something to women who happen to be married to men who are wealthy.
If my hon. colleagues on the other side learn nothing else from this debate, maybe they could learn for once that women who are merely married to men who are

September 15, 1992
Government Orders
wealthy do not by any means de facto have access to that wealth.
I know of women in every one of those neighbourhoods that I cited here today who have saved the baby bonus cheques sometimes for years to get out of violent situations, miserable situations, to save their lives and protect themselves. That is just one aspect.
My colleague from South Shore is laughing. Perhaps it does not happen in his riding, although I know differently. Perhaps he does not have personal knowledge of that but I do and other women in this House on both sides have knowledge of that.
The money is not going to Mr. Irving or Mr. somebody else. The money is going for the benefit of the family and for the benefit of the women and the children in the family. How well do you know each individual? How well do you know a family that may be listed very highly in Dun & Bradstreet corporation or in a financial listing? Does the hon. minister who just made a crack, the hon. President of the Treasury Board, really know what every individual wealthy family in this country is like on the inside? Does he really know and can he stand in his place and say that women who happen to be married to wealthy men do not live lives of quiet desperation? It is merely a small point but it is one that means something to women in this country.
If this government had any commitment to a sensible and fair tax system, we would not have this kind of foolishness emanating from it. Every time it takes the wrong end of the stick or, should I say, the wrong end of the horse. That is what it is taking here.
It tries to sell this to us by telling us that there are more benefits for low income families. There are not. It is wrong. The experts will tell you there are not more benefits. It will try and tell you that there are more effective benefits to those in greatest need. That is wrong too. It tries to tell you that it will make the child benefit system simpler and more responsive.
What the government effectively wants to do is what it has effectively wanted to do to this country since the day it took office in 1984 and has been putting upon the people of Canada ever since. That is a systematic and deliberate attack on the infrastructure and the social safety net of this country.
The time has come when Canadians are standing up from St. John's to Victoria and saying they will not have it. They will not have it in South Shore. They will not have it in Moncton, New Brunswick. They will not have it in the province of Quebec. They will not have it in Wild Rose and they will not have it anywhere in this country.
When that glorious day comes when the people of Canada can tell this government what they think of these ideas with regard to the sacrosanct sacred cows that they have dealt with, the government will know.
I will mark the hon. member's words and I also know how people will be marking their ballots on the South Shore. God help us, I cannot wait for the day.
We look at the child benefit program. We look at the history of the family allowance in this country. We look at the fact that in the 1930s when these programs came into being, they were brought about because of the greatest economic depression that the North American continent had ever seen.
We are living through a period of the second greatest economic downturn that this country has ever seen, and we are living through it because of the fiscal policies of this government. That is the answer.
My colleague in the New Democratic Party talked about Thatcherism and Reaganomics. These are the same things being practised by this government and that is why this country is suffering, that along with a misnamed free trade agreement.
Government policy has caused the hardship in this country. Canada survived the Dirty Thirties because of social programs. We are surviving now because of social programs. If this government keeps it up, we will not have this safety net and Canada as we know it will not survive.
It is sad that the primary attack of this government is against the women and the children.

Mr. Speaker, the effect of the motions being debated here today would be the outright cancellation of the child tax benefit.
In this respect, I am not quite sure if my hon. colleagues understand the implications of their motions.
I am surprised that they would want to take away a $2.1 billion increase in child benefits. This is particularly
September 15, 1992

perplexing since most of the money would be directed to low income families.
Are they trying to save money on the backs of low income families? If so, I fervently disagree.
I believe that if we were to adopt these motions, we would be giving up an historic opportunity to enrich child benefits and to improve the way they are delivered. Accordingly, let me take a moment to remind the House what this bill is all about.
I am a firm believer in the redistribution of scarce resources for the general benefit of all Canadians, particularly our children. It is a Canadian tradition of which we should be rightfully proud. It ranks high among the reasons why Canada is regarded by many as the best place in the world to live and to raise a family.
However, I also believe that our social programs have been strong and effective only because they have been amended and reformed over time to meet the changing needs of our society. That is why I strongly support Bill C-80. It will replace the traditional, and some may say antiquated, child benefit programs with a modem, fair, responsive and simple system.
Let me explain. For almost a century the Government of Canada has provided direct financial assistance to parents to help with the care and upbringing of their children. Over time, the benefits have evolved into a patchwork system which includes family allowance, child credit and a refundable child tax credit. This patchwork system of benefits is not sufficient to meet the needs and expenses of today's Canadian children and their parents. As identified by several national groups and scores of individual Canadians, this jumble of benefits has a number of shortcomings which must be addressed.
For example, Canadians agree that the current system does not provide enough support to lower-income families; especially lower-income working families. Many have expressed concern that targeting family allowances on the basis of individual income is unfair because families with similar incomes may receive different levels of benefits. Others have decried the delays faced by parents in receiving benefits as well the differing sets of eligibility criteria and delivery mechanisms.
The child tax benefit has been designed to rectify these and other shortcomings of the current system. For
Government Orders
instance, support to low-income families will be increased substantially. Over the next five years the child tax benefit will provide $2.1 billion in increased child assistance and 80 per cent of that new money will go to families with annual earnings under $40,000. Moreover, the new earned income supplement of up to $500 will help low-income working families offset employment related expenses and a possible reduction in social assistance benefits upon joining the work force.
The child tax benefit will also be fairer. Benefits will be targeted on the basis of family-rather than on individual-incomes. Families earning similar incomes will receive similar benefits. This will better ensure that assistance is directed according to family needs.
The child tax benefit will be more responsive to the current needs of Canadian children and their parents. Under the system now in place parents may face up to a year or more to receive their full refundable tax credit. Under the new system benefits will be provided on an up-front, monthly basis. This will ensure that benefits arrive when they are needed. It will also mean that parents will no longer feel the need to sacrifice portions of their benefits to tax discounters to obtain badly-needed cash.
As well, a family may now have to wait for a year or more to receive a full increase in benefits arising from a change in family status. This could be the birth of a child or the breakup of a marriage. Under the child tax benefit, monthly payments will be fully adjusted following a change in family status.
Finally, the child tax benefit will be simpler. The three different eligibility criteria and delivery mechanisms of the current system will be reduced to one. Payment will be in the form of a single, tax-free monthly cheque. Moreover, payment levels will be calculated automatically and the tax return will be shorter and less confusing. Gone will be the days when parents had to complete special calculations on their tax returns to receive child support. For higher-income families, the repayment of benefits to the government at year's end will also be a thing of the past. In short, the child tax benefit will simplify the tax system and streamline and substantially enrich the government's support for families with children. It responds to the changes urged upon the government by interested groups and individuals. I am pleased

Government Orders
to note that it has engendered world-wide support. Thank you for your support, Mr. Speaker.

Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to have a few moments to speak on this bill this morning. There are a number of reasons, the first of which concerns the content or the way it was introduced. In light of some of the comments made here today, in fact in the last few moments, there was an obvious attempt once again at circumventing parliamentary procedure and the purpose of this House.
Before I talk about the subject of the tax benefit I want to recall for the House a comment that was made by a colleague of mine last week when he spoke on the referendum. It was the member for Acadie-Bathurst. He talked about the credibility of the House and the credibility of those people who sit here. What is happening with this bill is the very reason Canadians are wondering why this is still called the highest court in the land.
We have Bill C-80 which talks about the child benefit which was introduced in the 1992 federal budget. It is overhauling, purports to overhaul or will overhaul if it is passed, a system that has been in effect for years. How has this happened? Before I address the content of whether it is right or wrong in terms of content, let me just have a look at the process.
This bill was introduced on June 1 for first reading. It had two days of debate when the government invoked closure on the second reading. It then went to committee. The committee sat, I understand, during the summer under the auspices of the finance committee. There was not even enough time to get expert witnesses to come and discuss the intricacies of this bill so that legislators, members of Parliament, of this highest court in the land could understand what was happening. As a parenthetical comment, every witness except one said that they thought this bill was wrong, unfair and unbalanced. All but one said that.
We are in the House now today for debate at report stage. The report from the government side says that it wants this to be the way it was when it was laid out in this white paper. We are proposing amendments. These amendments should take a week to go through in chapter and verse so that those people whom we serve
could know and decide for themselves whether they are getting a good deal or a bad deal.
This is the modus operandi for this government. Look at the number of times that closure has been invoked in this House. My figures tell me it was 31 times since this government came to power in 1984.1 am sorry. That was time allocation which essentially is the same as closure. Closure happened 19 times. That is a total of 50.
I was not able to find the records and I was not able to get the information, but I believe it has happened roughly one-tenth as much as in the history of this country since Confederation. This will give you some indication of what the process is and in how much detail this bill is being discussed.
I see the member for Wild Rose is just leaving. I really object to one of the statements she made. She gave all kinds of reasons and I guess she spouted out government-prepared memoranda and documents. One of the statements was: "How could anybody oppose a $2.1 billion increase in this program?"
What she did not say was that one has to measure this against the $3.5 billion that has already been taken out of the child benefit system in the last five years. If she thinks the Canadian public is being fooled by an additional $2.1 billion against a zero background, I want to remind the public that it is $2.1 billion for the next five years. That $2.1 billion is not as much in real terms as the $3.5 billion that was taken away five years before. If I were a bargainer and a gambler I would not call that a good deal.
I am now into the content of this bill. I am not going through what it says because there is no time and other speakers have talked on that subject. The assistance to the poorest families does not increase by anything at all.
There is the the long-awaited national child care strategy. I recall when I was campaigning four years ago that there was a great program introduced by the government that was going to come up with a child care program. As I understand it, it has been completely abandoned and it is creating additional hardship on low and middle-income families, of which I have many in my riding. It is very difficult for single-income families.
I have already spoken about the lack of consultation, but in my mind, in principle, that is the biggest difficulty with this bill. Once more we are reducing social benefits to Canadians and they are not getting the opportunity to

hear the debate by chapter and verse as it used to be done before 1984. I could go on.
One of the concerns that I really have is the business of indexation. It can be a difficult thing to understand. It can be an easy thing to understand. Essentially, deindexing will amount to a clawback that in the long term will hurt Canadian families.
I am not sure that we need any more of that because we have had an effect on people in my riding, a reduction in UI benefits, a cap on the Canada Assistance Plan which, while it does not pertain to my province, has a principle involved, a reduction in health payments, a reduction in co-operative housing payments and a reduction in transfer payments to Newfoundland including Bonavista-Trinity-Conception. This means less money for those who need it.
I do not profess to be an expert in the details of this. That is one of the reasons I wanted to be here when it was discussed. I could decide one way or another how I could explain it to those people who would ask me questions. I think I have enough information for that now. I wanted them to listen to the debate.
In the time remaining I really cannot do more than make a few comments on what these few witnesses who came before the committee had a chance to offer. I think the one that describes my feeling about the bill more than anything else is this: "To us it is clear that this so-called child benefit will be a detriment to the entire country, especially to children and eventually to seniors. Therefore, Bill C-80 should be thrown in the garbage can, not passed".
I think my hon. friend from Malpeque would tell me that that is almost a maritime description of something we do not like. I could not find more eloquent words to describe it.
We are in the process of debating our amendments. Our amendments essentially would deal with the deletion of the entire bill. That is first. Second, we would ensure that there would be full indexation of the benefit and of the threshold amounts. Third, we would include possibly a child benefits adjustment board to deal with the response to this problem.
Government Orders
I looked at a case last night and discussed it with the critic in this area. One could go as much as 18 months before an adjustment was made. There are an awful lot of people in this country in particular economic conditions who cannot wait 18 months for this kind of thing.
Finally, our amendments would ensure that the provinces cannot decrease the amount of the proposed benefit. Critics are concerned that a province could cap welfare payments as the new, combined benefits would provide a larger monthly amount to families.
I can conclude very quickly. I am concerned as a legislator that once more I am being cut off from information and I do not have enough time to discuss this with my colleagues on all sides of the House. I am concerned about the closure, I am concerned about the principle of parliamentary debate, and I am concerned that this is a rotten bill and we are being asked to pass it.
I for one will vote against it, and I think that most of the members on this side of the House also will.

Mr. Speaker, I was very quietly minding my own business over here listening to the debate, and I have been provoked into saying something about Bill C-80.
One of the things about this bill that strikes me as important, and it is something that Canadians have to think about-and we have said it time and time again-is that this bill destroys universality. The Tories come along and make this very specious argument that we do not need universality and that we need to re-focus the amounts of money we put into family allowances so that the real needy get money for the raising of their children.
What is at the root of universality? What is the root when we talk about family allowances and children? What we are saying with universality is that all Canadians are responsible for the raising of our children. These are not moneys directed to one group of children or to another group of children. It is not redistribution of wealth that we are really talking about here in this Tory package. Universality recognizes that all the children of Canada belong to all Canadians and that all of us have a responsibility to raise those children.

Government Orders
Bill C-80 is not new. The Tories did not dream this up. This was a Liberal machination.
Oh, oh.
Absolutely. The Tories are only Liberals in a hurry. I want them to keep that in mind. They are on a fast track to nowhere.
John, you will never change.

The minister says I will never change, but the minister must remember his history. It was Judy Erola, when she was minister, who proposed the idea that we had to get rid of family allowances and destroy their universality. She got into a whole lot of trouble when she made the famous, or infamous, statement: "What contribution do women make who stay at home and look after children?". That was the day that she started going downhill.
This refocusing did not start with Bill C-80 and the Tories. It started over here with the Liberal Party. Therefore, when Liberal members stand up and parade themselves as the greatest defenders of universal family allowances they ought to hang their heads in shame.
The polls must be really bad.
No, I am just trying to set the record straight. We have to put it right there so that Canadians remember Judy Erola, who was a Liberal minister.
Tell me about the polls.

The same Judy Erola, and we are going to hear a lot about patent protection, is the same one who is now the lobbyist for the pharmaceutical association. We have to keep these things in focus.
If we all accept the principle that all the children of Canada belong to all of us and that we all have to contribute it is not enough to go around saying that our children are our greatest resource and that our children are our future. We use children on the back of our loonies. The Prime Minister uses children for photo ops. Children wave their little flags and sing about how much they love Canada. We use children all the time. Yet when we look at what we are doing to them and their parents in this bill and in certain other actions of the government we realize that it is all phoney, that the government really does not like children. The Toiy government is anti-child. I want to say that and I want to put that on the record.
How else to describe a bill with the purpose of taking total amounts of money for family allowances and refocusing them so that the neediest get the most, when in fact the neediest do not get more? The neediest are those whose parents do not have work and are on social assistance. We call it welfare.
In this day and age there are all the cutbacks that this federal government has embarked upon, restructuring the economy, the recession that was brought on by this government, and all of the unemployment that has ensued, and the cutbacks in the unemployment insurance program that have forced people onto welfare. We hear the municipalities constantly complaining about the fact that they have to pick up the welfare costs now that all the people who have run out of UI are spinning onto it.
We have seen all of the job losses resulting from the free trade deal with the United States. The neediest of the neediest get not one penny more from this package, not one penny more.
However, those in the $125,000 a year bracket get more. Think about it. As a socialist I have often talked about class politics. It is my bread and butter to talk about working class people rather than the wealthy classes. I have always been told: "Oh, Rodriguez, you are always using the rhetoric of the 1930s. You are always going back to class politics".
Well if ever there is a bill that reinforces class politics it is Bill C-80. It puts parents and Canadians into classes. Those who are unemployed and are on welfare are the poorest of the poor and they get nothing more than they got before.
The working poor get $42 a month more per child. Those up in the next bracket, $40,000 to $60,000, get a little more. Those in the $120,000 a year bracket get more.
That is clearly dividing the community into classes. The government exploits class politics. The Tories are exploiters of classes and they trade off the rich against the poor.
This is the government that started deindexing. TMk about really stamping people down into the mud. It has kept the indexing of the family allowances at 3 per cent. Only if the inflation rate is above 3 per cent will the government reflect it in an indexation on the family allowances. If inflation is under 3 per cent there is no indexation. If it is 2.5 per cent it means that the amount

that the poorest of the poor are receiving is eroded even further.
The government has totally reneged on what it had promised with respect to, for example, a child care program. What happened to the child care program of the former health minister, now the Minister of Communications? Where is it today? If Tories really cared about children that is where they would put money. We do not have adequate child care in this country.
We hear all the pious statements across the way about how they are opposed, about how Tories do not like child abuse. Where is the adequate child care program? Where was the program that was promised?
Parliament had a committee. It studied the proposals and it's report is up on a shelf somewhere. This is a government that has no commitment to full employment. If we really want to show respect for children and for people we have to guarantee them a job, not use them as fodder in the war against inflation, stagflation, deflation, rheumatism, in-grown toe-nails and ptomaine poisoning.
If we have a commitment to full employment then we recognize that a person has dignity when they work. They do not really want to get welfare cheques. They want a job. They want a paycheque, not a welfare cheque.

Mr. Speaker, I thank you very much for giving me an opportunity to address the issue, especially after my hon. colleague has waxed so rhetorically and so eloquently from a partisan point of view on an issue that is very serious.
I say it is serious because he did begin on a rational level. That rational level would talk about the basic philosophy that underlies the directions of both this government and governments past.
Speaking of governments past, Mr. Speaker, I hope that you and those who are following this debate in the House will grant me the indulgence of falling into a partisan discussion for a moment because the hon. member who just preceded me has raised a question which must be addressed in order that we put this debate in its proper perspective.
Government Orders
From a Liberal point of view, when we were in government we initiated a series of legislative initiatives for which the member for Nickel Belt takes great pride. As a Canadian and as a member of this legislative body, the House of Commons, he should take great pride in those initiatives which we collectively as a government and as a people put forward.
They have served as a role model everywhere throughout the world and have been duplicated in many other jurisdictions. When he suggests that the government is engaging in some nefarious deed that follows fast upon the heels of a government that collapsed some 10 years ago then he is asking us to stretch our imagination just a little bit too far.
Most important, he does great injustice to the essence of this debate, which my colleagues from this side of the House, from the Liberal Party, have pinpointed with particular attention to the details both in the amendments and in the bill itself.
Those amendments, the essence of those details, address the directions of a government whose philosophy has gone sorely adrift. We have seen over the course of this last session a cap placed on CAP. The consequences of that are now seen in this legislation.
What has happened is that the government essentially said: "We will not assume the responsibility that we had accepted for the health and welfare of all Canadians everywhere in this country", initially under the guise of saying that those residents in provinces such as British Columbia, Alberta and Ontario, those three provinces that do quite well on their own, do not need the financial assistance that a federal government provides as part of its obligation to its citizens.
Nothing could be so silly. The Government of Canada does not subsidize the provinces. What it does is transfer back into the hands of its citizens the wealth which is generated by them and which is there for their benefit.
We have seen as well that the government, in order to facilitate the projects determined by deficit cutting and cost cutting, has attacked those most vulnerable, the seniors. We have seen over the course of these last several sessions the government slowly eating away, gnawing away, eroding the basis of support upon which seniors have come to rely, at a time when they are least

Government Orders
productive from an economic point of view, at a time when they would be most dependent upon the state which they had helped to found, to develop, and to enrich, a state and a government from which they are owed at least some dignity, some respect and in the final analysis a modicum of financial support.
In the city of Toronto from where I come, a senior citizen is asked to make do on some very bare minimum monthly payments. To add insult to injury, we say that in spite of the fact that this government has been unable to put forth an economic program that would take advantage of the great resources this country offers. We are going to show that we respect our seniors and we are going to raise their monthly amount by 33 cents. It is not even enough to cover the cost of a postage stamp to send a complaint to their local member of Parliament.
This kind of legislation in Bill C-80 hides the fact that the government is very restrictive, small "c" conservative and, if I could lapse again into partisanship, almost reactionary. Were I in another country, I might say that this is right wing republicanism. I am not and I will avoid saying that.
What we have is the initiation of a philosophy that says we no longer need to support those basic social pillars that identified us as a progressive society. Do it under the guise that we are going to make the system more efficient. Listen to us, we are going to pump over the course of the next five years-my colleagues look in askance, "five years?"-$2.1 billion. This is after pillaging those systems of $3.5 billion. The phrase "smoke and mirrors" comes to mind to those who follow what the government is doing.
There is no question that the government does not want a socially progressive set of legislation or pillars for our society. It is a dog eat dog world. The marketplace must reign supreme. It must have its dictates imposed upon the way that people behave, the way that people act out their lives in this country.
There is much to be said for the workings of the marketplace. Where are those kinds of principles, I say to my colleagues opposite, applicable to everybody in our
society and not just to those who are weakest from a financial point of view?
I pointed out to the minister responsible for the privatization of Petro-Canada some months ago that the Canadian government, so eager to cut the deficit and reduce the debt, to show fiscal responsibility, to help those who are in need, was more than quick to contribute to oil companies, some of them not even based in Canada. These were not tax grants but outright cash grants totalling $832 million between 1989 and 1990. Then the government has the courage to come before this House and say with the rationalization of its social programs it is going to pump in another $400-odd million dollars per year over the course of the next five years. Give us a break, as they say on the street. We cannot possibly all be that gullible or that stupid.
This is the same government that says it is making a progressive step forward when it gets out of the unemployment insurance scheme. It used to be a three-party program of government, employer and employee.
To get right out of that and to put the onus on the employer and the employee at a time of recession when neither the employer nor the employee could afford to make that contribution hurts those people who need it most.
We must keep in mind that much of what is being applied today is going to have a negative impact on those children who will be the men and women of tomorrow who will guide this country. I refer government members to the statistics they throw back at us, that if we do not pay today we will jpay tomorrow through education costs and through other social costs.
