Mr. Speaker, at this time when we are renewing our country's Constitution and focusing on Canada's promising future, it is comforting and instructive to also remember our rich past.
In Georgetown, one of the communities I am proud to represent in Parliament, that past includes strong Scottish heritage. Perhaps most symbolic of that is the Georgetown Girls' Pipe Band which this year is celebrating its 50th anniversary.
This band has performed with distinction across Ontario, Quebec, in the United States, and even in Scotland. The anniversary will be marked by a Scottish tattoo which I am sure will be impressive and majestic and to which I invite all members of this House.
My sincere congratulations to every one associated with this outstanding band and my thanks to all those in Georgetown and across the country who keep the flame of our heritage alive.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday the National Action Committee
on the Status of Women said that it could not support this constitutional deal.
In the same breath it claimed to be speaking on behalf of the women of Canada. It does not speak for me.

The Charlottetown agreement is not perfect, but for the women of Quebec, it is a step in the right direction. We must defend our rights by ensuring that Quebecers say yes to Canada and yes to protecting women's rights that are guaranteed in Canada's Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
We must say yes- because economic instability affects women particularly. We must say yes. Otherwise women will be among the first victims of economic and social problems. No, Mr. Speaker, Judy Rebick does not speak for me. I have my own voice and I will say "yes" on October 26.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to congratulate the Government of Canada for sending our ship Protecteur, together with engineers, Canadian Forces personnel, machinery, supplies and equipment, to Miami to assist the population of south Florida in getting life back together again.
I am sure it is not the intention to help the United States financially, but the Americans certainly need our competent, well organized and trained people to rebuild schools and public institutions so they can be working again.
I believe this is the kind of assistance that one neighbour ought to give to another.

Mr. Speaker, due to this government's lack of foresight and lack of commitment to training, many Islanders are being forced to stay home and collect unemployment benefits rather than spend the time upgrading their skills through the fee payer program.

September 15, 1992
The budgets have run diy for the fee payer program and those who are victims of this government's economic policies are now falling prey to this government's lack of commitment to retraining.
This government has cut $200 million over the past two years from the Canadian Jobs Strategy program. With unemployment at 11.6 per cent across this nation and 18.6 per cent in Prince Edward Island this is absolutely unforgivable.
I call on the federal government to take action to ensure that unemployed Islanders are given access to retraining.
It is better to have an unemployed individual in a classroom upgrading his or her skills than sitting at home waiting for a job offer that may be a long time coming.

Mr. Speaker, Simon Israel, former head of mergers and acquisitions in ScotiaMcLeod's New York office, was fired mainly because he objected to anti-Semitic remarks from a senior officer who commented: "There's one that Hitler missed".
This comment was made in reference to a Jewish colleague who also was fired. Documents obtained by The Globe and Mail show that ScotiaMcLeod admits the Hitler comment was made and later repeated several times by ScotiaMcLeod's New York president.
We have to be constantly on guard to ensure that when racism rears its ugly head we promptly repudiate it. In our society racism starts in anodyne and anecdotal ways, then becomes part of a culture that spreads like fire.
Knowing the senior officials of Scotiabank, the parent company of ScotiaMcleod, I am convinced they do not countenance racist remarks. It is incumbent upon them to dissociate themselves from these statements and to deal effectively with the executive or executives responsible for these injurious words.

Mr. Speaker, I urge the government to press on with negotiations
with the Governments of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island to fund the Atlantic expressway. This proposed highway system, combined of course with the fixed link to P.E.I., is essential if any real improvement is to be made in the economies of Atlantic Canada.
Reduced rail services have had a negative impact on transportation while industry demands immediate and economic delivery of goods and services. The benefits of our location adjacent to the major markets of the northeastern United States can only be realized with an up-to-date highway system.
I urge that all parties re-energize their negotiations in the interest of completing this project which is in the interest of all Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, on October 26 all Canadians will be asked to take a stand on the Charlottetown consensus report. It will be an important vote in our nation's history.
The August 28 constitutional agreement is not perfect but it is the best that this government could give us. I have some reservations about the weakness of provisions on economic union and the Senate. Obviously, we have an equal Senate at the expense of an effective one. Nevertheless, we think that these deficiencies can eventually be corrected.

As a member of Parliament from the only officially bilingual province in Canada, I am pleased that this new deal will at last recognize and enshrine in the Constitution the equal status of New Brunswick's two official linguistic communities.
I anticipate working together with all political parties, interested groups and individual citizens of Restigouche-Chaleur in support of this agreement despite its shortcomings.
Furthermore, I urge the citizens of my riding to
examine this document and, most important, to vote and
voice their opinion on October 26.

Mr. Speaker, for months the Germain family of Val-d'Or, Louis and Clemence, have been trying everything to find solutions for their seven children who are all under 10 years old. They have something against Canada's tax system: they think that the Canadian government should consider the number of dependants, namely the wife and children, and the husband's salary, regardless of the income earned from all other sources.
That is a typical example of a large family in Canada that is penalized by the Canadian tax system.

Mr. Speaker, I have received more than 50 calls in my constituency office in Winnipeg asking for information on the constitutional proposals and the referendum. People want a copy of the consensus report. They also want a brief description in an unbiased kind of way, possibly preferably by a third party, of what these proposals are all about.
The government spends millions of dollars on advertising and trying to make itself feel better than it deserves. Surely it can address this issue which is an urgent one right now.

The citizens of Canada want to make an enlightened decision on October 26, so they need information.

I call upon the government to make this information available now.

Can we make sure that our fellow Canadians have the information they need to make a good decision on October 26 and vote yes?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I wish to join my friend, the hon. member for Mississauga South, in bringing to the attention of the House the mission of the HMCS Protecteur which is down in Florida right now helping with the reconstruction efforts after Hurricane Andrew.
The Protecteur departed from Halifax as we all know on September 10 carrying building supplies, tools and vehicles for use in rebuilding two heavily damaged schools in Dade county. The vessel docked yesterday and our crew has already begun working on the sites. The over 300 crew and specialists on the ship will be assisted by Canadian Air Force engineers who had arrived over the past weekend.
Around the world, through humanitarian actions like this and the efforts such as the UN peacekeeping forces, Canada is noted for its willingness to assist people and countries in need.
I think Canadians should recognize the blessings that such catastrophes are very rare in our country. I extend my appreciation to the involved Canadian Forces personnel and their Commander Douglas MacLean.
I am sure that British Columbians in Esquimau and Victoria will provide the Protecteur a warm welcome once it returns to its west coast base after this mission.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday in the House we heard the minister of trade repeatedly state that his arguments in favour of NAFTA were based on fact. At the same time he repeatedly denigrated the opposition for spreading misinformation. And yesterday was no different.
On a point of order just after Question Period the trade minister stated he wanted to clarify an error in his trade ads which the member for Windsor-St. Clair, that is myself, had clearly shown to be incorrect. However, this trade minister chose to further misstate the facts. He compared unadjusted March employment to unadjusted June employment.

S. o. 31
Had opposition members done that, he would surely have jumped all over us for misusing statistics. Unadjusted stats are used in year-over-year comparisons or by statistical incompetents. The facts he should have used to compare the months within the same year are those that had been seasonally adjusted to remove distortions. Seasonally adjusted manufacturing jobs in July 1992 totalled 1.8 million while in March 1992 they totalled
1,760,000,	a difference of only 43,000 jobs.
In fact the NAFTA propaganda distorted the facts, and that is what we pointed out here yesterday.

Mr. Speaker, I regret the Reform Party is against the Charlottetown accord because it is not perfect. The Reform Party wants to ignore our constitutional problems, thinking they will go away.
How can a five-year moratorium solve an issue? Will aboriginal peoples have to wait five years for justice? Will Canadians be stuck with the same tired old unelected Senate for five years and maybe forever? Will Canada's international economic reputation be damaged by the uncertainty of our country's future?
Most Canadians have enough common sense not to allow the perfect to be the enemy of the good. I fear Preston Manning has contempt, utter contempt, for common sense.

Mr. Speaker, last week the Prime Minister presented a proposed constitutional agreement. He said that it was the most important reform since Confederation in 1867 and that the negotiations had been an unprecedented success. Personally, like many others in Quebec and even in Canada, I have always maintained that it was not an agreement but rather a draft or a preliminary version.
Again today we see in La Presse that the Prime Minister of Canada and Mr. Bourassa are continuing to write to each other because they do not have a common understanding. That proves this is a draft and it is scandalous to ask Canadians to vote on a proposal that is only a draft. It is outrageous to spend $125 million for the pleasure of satisfying political parties.

Mr. Speaker, a towering giant in the field of journalism has died. Bruce Hutchison, one of Canada's leading authorities on political and economic affairs, died yesterday at his Victoria area home where he had lived since the 1920s. He was 91. He was editor emeritus of The Vancouver Sun where he wrote a weekly column until illness struck him just a few weeks ago.
Mr. Hutchison was truly a national treasure. Besides being a working journalist for 74 years, he wrote 15 books which helped define and shape the Canadian identity.
Although known for his shrewd insight and gifted writing skills, his first love was that of the outdoors which, he said, was the source of his wisdom. He worked at a time when it was fashionable for pre-eminent commentators to hob-nob with prime ministers, and he met all of them going back more than 70 years. That era is now over.
Bruce Hutchison was honoured by Canada several times including an appointment to the federal Privy Council this past July. He was indeed a great Canadian.
Hear, hear.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)

Mr. Speaker, let me first of all say that I am satisfied with the Charlottetown proposals that will serve to renew Canada's Constitution after October 26.

In August, when the Minister of Agriculture addressed a rally in the Melfort area, he added exports and imports together to show a massive increase in trade even though the true figures almost balanced out. This genius at manipulating the analysis is mind-boggling.
Yesterday the Minister for International Trade tried again. He altered the trade data, even though the member for Windsor-St. Clair had the actual tables from StatsCan right in front of him and the minister was wrong.

Mr. Speaker, in British Colombia we have a situation where there is a major change under way in the fishery as the aboriginal people are admitted to take their place in the fishery in accordance with the judgment of the Supreme Court of Canada delivered in 1990.
There are major changes under way in which we are trying to involve the aboriginal people by entering into agreements with them for conservation purposes, the healthy management of fish resources, and several experimental agreements under which certain groups are
September 15, 1992

allowed to sell fish for the first time in many years this year. This results in tensions.
As a result of these tensions, a great deal has been made of a situation with respect to the alleged disappearance of salmon going up the Fraser River from the Mission Bridge to the spawning grounds.
All of the runs of salmon are not completed yet in British Columbia up the Fraser River. We do know that in the early short run some 110,000 less salmon reached the spawning grounds than we thought would make it there.
There may be several reasons for that. It might be poaching. If so, we do not know who the poaching was done by since the poachers were not caught. It may be environmental conditions because of the warmer summer in British Columbia this year.
Or it might be that the electronic equipment used at the Mission Bridge is not accurate enough. It is like a poll; it is plus or minus 20 per cent in its calculations. Next year we intend to have two pieces of equipment there to check. There are all kinds of reasons why it may be that some salmon did not reach the spawning grounds.
The significant thing is this, that this was the best year for sockeye salmon on the Fraser River at this stage of a cycle in 80 years. It was the best year in 80 years and that is the thing that should be noted.

That unit, the B.C. region of the department, will be reporting to me after a thorough investigation on what they think occurred this year and what improvements may need to be made. We have already decided on a number of improvements for next year, including new equipment at the Mission Bridge for the counting of salmon that go into the river, the use of helicopters for patrol purposes, increased enforcement, new regulations with reference to the use of sales slips. I could go on and on.
If I do not get a satisfactory explanation from the Department of Fisheries and Oceans with reference to what happened this year, I am quite willing to consider having an independent inquiry into the situation. Nothing sinister has happened. It is regrettable that some fish did disappear this way. Our B.C. salmon stocks are not in danger. Forty-five thousand salmon reached the spawning grounds in the early short run, which is the second highest number ever to reach the spawning grounds there. We had been hoping it would reach the record again this year, but it did not. It is still the second highest ever. So B.C. salmon stocks are not in danger whatsoever.

Mr. Speaker, the government made an agreement back in 1990 with Seafreez providing for the operation of the fish plant at Burgeo and assigning specific groundfish quotas for that purpose.
As the minister noted, the company now says it plans to breach that 1990 agreement by processing the Burgeo quota at other plants.
I want to ask the minister what he plans to do to see to it that Seafreez keeps its end of the bargain and failing that, would he agree to undertake to see to it that local interests are enabled to take over the operation of the fish plant at Burgeo and be assigned the appropriate quotas to do so?

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as usual there are quite a number of complicated facts with respect to this situation. The Seafreez plant at Burgeo was closed in April. The reasons given then were the absence of a labour contract, labour productivity problems, and plant infrastructure problems.
Several years ago, as a result of the efforts of my predecessor as the minister of fisheries, the Seafreez company was able to take over the operation of the plant at Canso, Nova Scotia and a plant at Burgeo, Newfoundland from National Sea Products with considerable assistance from the government and the allocation of quite a considerable amount of various species of fish.

to be transferred from National Sea was to be processed
at Burgeo, 50 per cent at Canso and 60 per cent at Canso

of certain other underutilized species and 40 per cent at Burgeo. That still remains the case.

That Bill C-80 be amended in Clause 15 by adding immediately after line 3 at page 21 the following:

He said: Mr. Speaker, I rise today to continue the efforts on behalf of the Liberal caucus to improve this piece of legislation or if not, to defeat it.
In this particular Motion No. 38 we would like to address the question of changing circumstances for Canadian families. However, before I go on to that, I think I would be remiss if I did not speak to the issue of the time allocation vote we had this morning. This marks an anniversary of sorts. This marks the 50th time that this government across from us has used either closure or time allocation to cut off debate. I must say with some sadness that it is one of the first times it has used it against children of this country and in the debate on one of the most important issues in social policy.
We have tried several times in the last few years in House of Commons subcommittees and in different forums across the country to bring to the public's attention the questions and issues surrounding child poverty. The fact that the government moves in quickly with time allocation within 24 hours of the beginning of the debate, when this House sets upon to debate it, is the very real sign and indicator of its commitment to children's poverty.
The fact that the government has all its rhetoric for helping out families, but when push comes to shove it does not have the time to talk about it, is something that I hope every Canadian voter will remember in the coming year.
In this legislation there is an anomaly which I think should be addressed by the House before this legislation passes. If the government fails to address it then the legislation should be defeated on this point alone.
When the government set up this piece of legislation it made the decision to base the benefits received by each family on an income year-December 31 of a particular year-then not make adjustments to that until the following July 1 or 18 months later. This means that the

government has set up a bureaucratic process which has absolutely no ability to adjust to people's changing circumstances. If I can use my time in the House this way, then I would like to point out a few situations in which it could be disastrous for families.
Here is an example. Say that somebody is working in Calgary in the oil and gas industry. It would not be unusual for a professional to be making over $66,000 a year. Let us say that one professional in the family was working and making $66,000 a year with three children. Under the current system this family would not be receiving any benefits under the program. However, if on January 2 of that year the income earner was laid off, they would be immediately into UI which is a drop in income from $66,000 to $22,000. The UI would continue for one year at which point the family would have to turn to other methods of supporting themselves. There is, for example, social assistance.
Look at that evolution. A family in the lower-income levels would be receiving, for the three children, at least $270 a month plus some other benefits. Let us just round it out and say the family would be receiving $300. The family, under the way the government has set up this system, would not have access to that money for a full 18 months after their change in circumstances. For a family of five, $300 a month could represent, in very modest circumstances, a substantial portion of a food bill. However, instead of being able to respond and to be able to assist these families, the government is sitting back and leaving it up to the provinces or the municipalities to look after it.
One should stop and think about it. Look at the growth of food banks, for example, and the growth and need for nutrition programs in the schools across this country. One begins to realize that the fact that it has set in motion another piece of legislation which is inflexible and not responsive means that once again families in distress, going through absolutely wrenching experiences in trying to maintain income levels at a very difficult time, do not have access to the support which is being advertised across the country as a brave new way of assisting families. The very time one needs assistance, one cannot get access to it.

From time to time one is struck in the House by the way that other people tell the story of poverty and what it means. Tonight the CBC television network will show a program called Voices from the Shadows. It is the voices of people in poverty talking about their lives and their difficulties.
The face of poverty has changed in this country pretty dramatically. People who a few years ago could not imagine themselves being poor, now find themselves poor. Mr. Speaker, we have been discussing over the last day or so the government's proposals to respond to the problem of children in poverty.
Today we have seen the government impose extra speed to the debate. It is not prepared to let this debate go its full course and to allow all those who want to to speak in the House about this serious issue and the serious misdirection that the government is following. It is, as always, reprehensible to cut short a debate. However, in this particular case which deals with the children of Canada and the future of Canada-our most valued resources as I think we all would agree-it is particularly reprehensible to shorten the debate to force this bill through as this government is doing.
I would like to limit my comments on this amendment to just a couple of points. First, within this section and
within this proposal, the government is finally ending universality in child benefits in the so-called family allowance. The argument we have heard many times is why should the bank president and the rich get some income support from the government to raise their children? Why should that money not be taken away from those who are better off and given to those who are less well off and who really need it most?
On the surface of course it is an argument which has some merit, but it is not an argument which calls for the end of universality. With a fair and progressive taxation system we, of course, would be taxing back most of that child payment. So, in terms of the fiscal reasons or the financial reasons why the government presents itself as being concerned about this issue, it really is a much smaller issue that the government would have us believe.
There are many much larger tax benefits that the rich in Canada have, benefits that are larger than this family allowance. Why would we not look at taking those away from the richest of Canadians rather than just dealing with this little family allowance? Why in that process would we be saying to all Canadians that raising children is not as important as it once was? Surely, as we all know, the rationale behind the universal family allowance is that it costs money to raise children. Children are the future of the country and will pay the taxes in the future and will work and contribute to the economy of the country. Consequently, we need to recognize those extra costs for raising children and support, albeit in a relatively small way, the efforts of those parents, not only on behalf of the parents and their children but on behalf of the country as a whole.
We are taking away the universal family allowance, saying that it is no longer appropriate for the country to recognize that all those who are raising children are contributing to the public good in that process.
An important argument in favour of keeping universality is that it is a much cheaper program to administer. Universal programs are very efficient to administer because of low administration costs as they go to everyone and then are taxed back via the taxation system. In terms of efficiency and cheapness it is appropriate to have universality.

The most important reason is that evidence from those countries, particularly European countries with universal programs, shows that they have the lowest child poverty rate. In other words, there is a link between universal programs and effective child benefit programs. Those countries, particularly the Scandinavian and northern European countries, that have universal programs and where there is not a push to remove universality have done a much better job than countries with targeted programs in dealing with child poverty. Of the developed nations, the United States is the only country with a worse child poverty rate than Canada's. Countries such as Sweden and Norway with universal programs have child poverty rates of approximately one quarter of those in Canada.
Universality works. It makes for a better response to children's concerns and the desire to maintain them at a standard which enables them to fulfil their desires and expectations more fully than is the case if they are poor.
The other point I want to discuss in this context is with regard to the contrast between children who live in poor families that work and those who live in poor families that unfortunately cannot work. In an economy with 11.6 per cent unemployment, and officially the rate is going to be much higher than that, on average one in seven or eight households will have an unemployed person in it. We can see how difficult it is at the present time for Canadians to obtain employment. They are not unemployed because they want to be, contrary to what lies behind some of the comments from the other side. They are unemployed because they cannot find jobs. It may also be that they are unemployed because they do not have the required skills.
Children who live in poverty, whether they live in a poor family that works or a poor family that does not work, do not choose to live in poverty. It is entirely accidental that they are bom to poor parents. It is entirely accidental to them that their parents work or do not work.
Under this legislation if they happen to be bom to poor parents who do not work, that family will be $500 worse off than if it is fortunate enough to work.

on behalf of children because it is clear that rationale is not likely to end with this particular proposal but is likely to be considered in the context of others as well.
For example, there are very real concerns about Canadian pensions and medicare. Are we going to say that the rich should not have access to those programs as well? In that context, the same point goes for universality as it does in the context of family and child benefits.
At the risk of reiterating something that I said yesterday, it is really time that this government address the real problem and not tinker around the edges. That is what is happening here. For the poorest of Canadian children, not one extra penny will be available to them. To those who are not quite so poor, such a small amount of money available to them will really not make a huge difference, certainly not enough to those children and those families out of poverty. Lest we see that it is an unrealizable dream to raise poor Canadian children above the poverty line, as the Minister of National Health and Welfare has said, there are countries like Sweden where child benefits bring poor families up above the poverty line. It is not such an odd notion that we should not put up with one million children living in poverty.
It is time that the government address the real problem with real solutions. It is not only unfortunate but it will be a terrible future for Canadian children because this government does not address those real concerns.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to stand in the House today to speak to the amendments to Bill C-80, a bill to repeal the Family Allowances Act. I congratulate my colleague from Winnipeg North Centre who has put forward many amendments to this very regressive bill.
This bill, should it pass in the House of Commons, really means the end of universality as we have known it in Canada for a good many years. Concerning the three existing programs, some of which have been traditionally available to all families regardless of income, this new system will bring an end to them.
This contrast between the deserving poor and the The government is doing it as a way to help children in undeserving poor is one which troubles those of us on low income families. This is a fallacy because those who this side of the House. It also troubles all those who work are on welfare will not get one penny more.

Government Orders
The partial deindexation of the benefit and complete lack of indexation of the threshold amounts will result in the gradual erosion of the benefit amount as well as lessen the number of families eligible for the benefit.
At present there is no proper mechanism to ensure that dramatic changes in family income are reflected in the monthly benefit amount. As it stands now, it could take up to 18 months for the benefit to be adjusted.
Another major concern is the lack of a federal-provincial arrangement which could result in the provinces capping welfare payments.
This bill signifies the end of universality and the end of recognition of the higher expenses parents incur in raising children today.
The family of a woman who probably enjoys a combined income in her family and is probably above that threshold would in turn be paying back any benefits it had received through the family allowances over the years. It would be paying that back in income tax at the end of the year. This woman said to me she knew that every month she was getting a cheque for her children. She could spend it whichever way she wanted on those children. She could give it to them or she could make allowances for whatever. It was something that she looked forward to even though she realized that she had to pay it back at the end of the year. Now this government is taking it away.
The beginning of the end began long ago. While the government boasts that this legislation signifies an estimated $2.1 billion increase over five years to the child benefits system, we must remember that $3.5 billion has already been taken out of the child benefits system between 1986 and 1991.
The long awaited and promised national child care strategy, a significant deterrent to child poverty, has been completely abandoned, creating additional financial hardship on low and middle income families, especially single parent families. This government has brought forward several initiatives which have negatively affected poor families, such as the cap on the Canada Assistance Plan.
Another area of concern is over what this legislation might mean for women in our society. Some women in
abusive relationships, as an example, will now be losing their only form of income, the family allowance. The statistics speak for themselves. Many women feel trapped in these relationships because the only thing that separates them from the poverty abyss is the income of their abusive male partner. Now they are losing their only independent source of income.
It has been established that one of the main reasons for spousal violence against women is the need to control. What better way to control someone than by depriving them of all financial resources? For these women family allowances has been a life-saving buoy.
There are other areas of concern regarding this legislation: the lack of consultation both before and after the release of the white paper; the manner and speed with which the Conservative government is trying to drive the legislation through Parliament unamended; the fact that the Minister of National Health and Welfare would not appear before the committee to defend his proposal which supports the disturbing trend under the Conservative government of transferring social policy to finance; the regressive nature of the increased child care deduction; the enrichment of the RRSP tax deduction which will cost the government millions of dollars in unclaimed revenue and be of assistance only to higher income groups.
The government through this legislation will be using $500 million to provide bigger monthly payments to a carefully targeted group of low income Canadians, thereby creating an illusion of wealth for thousands of low income Canadians in the months leading up to the next election.
Early in January, just as people are coping with paying holiday bills, they will get a big increase in their monthly cheques. For example, a two-child family with an annual income of $30,000 will get $153 a month instead of $70. A few months later, at income tax time, it will be able to claim the usual child tax credits. The government is hoping that most will not realize that it will be their last opportunity for claiming the usual child tax credits. The government is hoping that no one will realize when it is election time, possibly next spring, that their cheques will begin to decrease in July because they are not indexed to inflation.

The government is hoping that low income families will not realize at election time that they will not receive in November their usual $800 first instalment of their 1993 refundable child tax credit. There will be no such thing any more if this legislation goes through.
This is a government that is deceitful at its worst. The government is hoping that no one will realize when it is time to vote that their child credits have disappeared from the tax system as they have all been rolled into the bigger monthly cheques sent out in the initial months of this plan.
This is creative financing at its best. Government spin doctors have been having a field day.
This bill is flawed. It is deceitful and it is unnecessary. It will hurt every Canadian family with children, particularly those families impoverished or on the brink of poverty and also women in unfortunate situations of abuse or neglect. It is not too late for this government to listen to some reason and to have a conscience for these people and these families in situations in which they cannot afford to do without this.
I ask the government to reconsider, to take this bill back and seriously look at the flaws that are inherent in it.

Mr. Speaker, I cannot help but make a few comments on this legislation.
On November 24, 1989 the House of Commons adopted a resolution. I will read this resolution into the record. It states:
That this House express its concern for the more than one million Canadian children currently living in poverty and seek to achieve the goal of eliminating poverty among Canadian children by the year 2000.
That was supported by the House of Commons.
Fairly recently, in fact I think it was last May, we approved and became a part of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. In fact, Canada co-chaired this convention. We were very proud and honoured to see our country playing such a leadership role at the international level in trying to promote the rights of children abroad. That is to be commended, but since May 1992 we have seen no national strategy and no action plan.
Government Orders
The only thing we have heard to date is a comment made by the Minister of National Health and Welfare on May 7, 1992 when he was asked by one of my colleagues about his plans concerning child poverty in Canada. His comment at the time was that there were no specific plans to deal with child poverty.
It led me to believe that what we have put in writing in this House and what we have voted on is not really what we are taking action on. In other words, it is the public at large that is going to look at the action of this Parliament and the vote of this House with suspicion, and rightly so because it has been deceived more than once.
I say this because we have poverty in our country. In fact, one out of every six children in Canada lives in poverty. As well, the death rate of poor children is 50 per cent higher than it is for members of the population with higher incomes. When we look at aboriginal children in Canada we find that their life expectancy is at least eight years shorter than the national average. Suicide is the second leading cause of death among Canadian adolescents. I would suggest that figure would increase for poor children.
Let us examine the illiteracy rate of high school students and the drop-out rate of over 30 per cent. All these things require an over-all national strategy to deal with this question. We require a collective effort, not only on the part of the federal government but on the part of the provincial and municipal governments.
Unfortunately, the person or the group or the government that has taken the lead so far on child poverty has abandoned it and has passed it on to other levels of government without any sense of responsibility or any sense of accountability. That is very sad. That is why we are seeing the third sector, the non-profit sector, stepping in to fill the gap. That is also why church organizations are being forced on their own, without any kind of assistance or involvement from the government, to use their own resources to try to help fight child poverty.
I have one example of those who are working tirelessly. Members of St. Andrew's Church in my riding have circulated a petition nation-wide-I assume that all members in this House will be approached to circulate this petition in their ridings-urging the government to keep its commitment when it comes to dealing with child

Government Orders
poverty and promising to eliminate child poverty by the year 2000.
Another level of government, the Regional Municipality of Ottawa-Carleton, in our national capital region, has unanimously passed a resolution calling on the federal government to take action and keep its promise in trying to deal with child poverty in Canada.
These are not enough. It is the responsibility of the federal government to not only direct the traffic but also to send a proper signal to those other partners that we are serious about what we are doing.
It is not fair for legislation to be put in place that tries to tell the community out there that we are trying to help them if they are poor, the working poor, or of middle income when what we are doing is taking money away from them.
I am talking about the supplement that the government has decided in its own wisdom not to link to inflation or to the cost of living. Anyone, whether in the private sector or the public sector, knows that we live in a society where there is not always zero inflation.
As a matter of fact, in the 1980s the inflation rate was over 12 per cent. With a 12 per cent inflation rate and a zero per cent increase in the supplement for those poor families these people will be losing over 12 per cent on an annual basis. Inflation has eaten away at the supplement that the government is saying that it is giving them.
Second, we are putting in place legislation that gives responsibilities to other levels of government without telling people that there are any strings attached. We know too well what happens to transfer payments for education. Provinces take the money from the federal government, turn around and spend it on bridges and roads. Our institutions suffer as a result of that.
We have an incredible illiteracy rate. We have an incredible drop-out rate in our schools. We have an incredible drop-out rate in our universities. Simply put, this is because we do not have enough resources at the institutional levels. This is no different from what will happen with the new legislation.
My colleague from Nepean mentioned that this marks the end of universality. If we do not want to be so radical
in our assumption, if it is not, it is half way to ending universality in our country.
We are saying this because we believe that there is a need for a national strategy to deal with child poverty. There is a need for a national strategy to attack the question of poverty, not for half measures that hurt those who need our help the most. These half measures are not helping the poor.
That is why I and my colleagues have been encouraging the government to look at and deal with some of those amendments which were put before the minister and the government.
What happened? We had closure. Tomorrow we must go to third reading and rubber stamp the bill whether we want it or not so that it will become a law in January 1993. That is not very fair. It is not very fair because we have to allow a proper consultation to take place. We have to examine it and do an impact study to determine whether this bill as it is fits into what we have already committed ourselves, which is to eliminate child poverty by the year 2000.
We also must look at this bill and determine whether it fits with what we have promised. Not only Canadians but every country all over the world must see that we are serious about dealing with the question of child poverty in our country. Frankly, what we have before us does not address the question at hand. In fact, it falls into a hole on its own.
The government is making a major error in moving very quickly without a proper assessment of this legislation.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to again speak on this most important legislation.
I would like to point out to the hon. member who spoke before me that we do think it is haste when the government is trying to undo 50 years of social policy in this country in seven months.
The past seven months when this Parliament has been in adjournment, has been preoccupied with the Constitution, has been preoccupied with high unemployment, has been preoccupied in completing the trade deals, this government has been sweeping aside 50 years of social policy.
Yes, we are upset. Yes, we are saying that this government is acting with undue haste. Fifty years of Canadian social policy is going down the tubes. One of the things that is most striking about this whole debate is that it is taking place the same week that we are setting

September 15, 1992
Government Orders
out on a referendum to try to keep this country together, a unity referendum some people are calling it.
If you go right across this country and ask people what identifies us as Canadians, what makes us different from the Americans, what keeps us together, they will identify social programs. Traditionally they would identify three social programs: old age pensions that everybody received; family allowance that everybody received; and medicare that everybody received without fear of financial bankruptcy.
A mother in the Gaspe peninsula or in Pouce Coupe, B.C. or in northern Alberta or New Brunswick would say that she is in receipt of the same family allowance for all ox her children. It was a unifying force. It was something that identified us as distinctly Canadian.
It is like a ball game. It is three strikes and you are out. Old age pensions are gone as a universal program. Family allowance will be gone as a universal program. This bill makes it no longer a universal program.
That leaves medicare, which is under attack as a universal program because of the government's cutbacks to the provinces which lessens their ability to pay for universal health care. In fact, the medical association in British Columbia has said clearly that universal health care programs are no longer sustainable in Canada and that it is a policy of the B.C. Medical Association to no longer have universal health care.
With all of these wrapped together, the very fabric of Canada is under attack by this government at a time when we should be launching into a unity debate about keeping this country together.
This is also bad social policy. In fact, I had the opportunity to speak earlier about the whole question. This goes back to the Elizabethan poor law, the deserving poor and the undeserving poor. It is also based on another fundamental flaw in income security programs, and that is the concept of categorical assistance.
Categorical assistance was developed in conjunction with the concept of the deserving and undeserving. There were various categories, and the assistance rates varied, not based on their economic need, not based on their social conditions, not based on what it would take to ensure that they were above the poverty line, but based on their category.
Therefore, there was the blind person's allowance, handicapped person's allowance, veterans' allowance, mother's allowance. It was a long time before men who were unemployed were given any kind of assistance. They were in the lowest of categories in terms of categorical assistance. This is now perpetuating it because we are now going back to a concept of categorical assistance.
This is no longer a universal family allowance program. This is a categorical income assistance program. Certain people in one category will get a certain amount of money. Other people who happen to be working and are now deemed deserving, will get additional money, an additional $42 per month per child. The poorest of the poor, the ones who have no earned income, get less.
If you really sit and think about this, what are the case examples? A mother who has been working, trying to support her two children on $11,000 year loses her job because of the trade deal. What does the government do? It takes away from her $84 a month. It is incredible. Here is a working poor mother who loses her job and what do we do in this legislation? We say to her: "You are only half down, we will kick you down a little farther, we will take away another $84". It is an incredibly stupid social policy. The mother who is living with an abusive husband, who after a certain length of time deserts her, what do we do to her? We say to the mother: "Your husband has deserted you so we are going to take away your family allowance because there is no income coming in. He is considered a single person paying single income tax on his own. What we are going to do is take away your family allowance".
We say to the abused mother or the children who are being abused: "Do not dare leave that abusive husband. Do not dare leave that person who is abusing your children because if you do we are going to take away your $84 a month. We are going to make it as difficult and as impossible for you as we possibly can". This is bad social policy.
I wish the Conservative government had gone back and read a few books on the development of social policies and income security programs in Canada. It would have realized that what it is doing is going back to the whole concept of the deserving and the undeserving poor, the concept of categorical assistance, where assistance is provided, not based on need, not based on what it takes to live, but based on various categories. There is
September 15, 1992

a category of the working mother and the category of the non-working mother.
At the same time this government is making it extremely difficult for the provinces to deal with family poverty, particularly the larger provinces, Alberta, B.C. and Ontario where it has cut back dramatically on the Canada Assistance Plan. The Canada Assistance Plan is designed to provide income assistance to the very poor, the people who have no other source of income.
A witness before the committee said it best: "I think it is critical to remember that children are not poor in themselves. They are poor because their parents do not have enough money". That is what we have.
Mr. Speaker, you are signalling that my time is up. Unfortunately for many Canadians, it may be that the time is up for family allowances. I would just remind Canadians that it is strike two on universal programs. Old Age Security is gone, family allowance is gone and the only thing left is medicare, which if this government continues its present course on social policy will also be gone.

I do not know if it does any good to confuse the Canadian public as to what is actually happening here. He makes statements to the effect that we are eroding certain programs that we have in this country. That is totally inaccurate. He is suggesting that we are tearing up or destroying the very fabric of Canada. That is a total exaggeration.

Some of the fundamentals of this program have to be explained, and I do not think he has done a very fair job of that. What we are talking about is a bill that will replace an existing patchwork of benefits into one new package. This new package will be called the child tax benefit. We are taking three patchwork programs and replacing them with one.
I question whether the members on the other side actually read the pamphlet that the minister, who is with us today in the House, put out explaining the program. In fact, it reached many Canadians; I know it reached my constituents. They have read it and have responded well to it. This booklet called The Child Benefit outlines clearly what we want to do. It is far different from what the member has just suggested.
In very simple terms, what we want to do is replace three patchwork programs with one program that works.
What will the net result be? The net result will be that it will put more money into the hands of Canadian families that need it. It will put more money into the hands of Canadian families. That is something which the opposition ignores completely. They have ignored it all week in this debate. The fundamental truth of this program is that it puts more money into the hands of Canadian families that need it.
I will explain to my constituents quite openly that if they earn over $70,000, this program will not benefit them. I will admit that. I will admit that this program will benefit no one that makes over $70,000 in this country. But those people are not complaining about this program anyway because under the present patchwork system, the family allowance is taxed back anyway. They are saying, why give me something that will simply be taken away come tax time? So that is what we have done.
I have letters on file in my office from my constituents actually complaining "why do you send out this thing?" and the constituent explains "this thing called family allowance, only to tax it back at the end of the year?" I suggest he is absolutely right. Why would we do it?
That is what we are doing with this new program, as is so clearly explained by the minister in this pamphlet. The minister steps through what this program will do for Canadian families. If the NDP wants to argue that it is

Government Orders
going to hurt Canadian families that need it most, that is a fallacious argument, it is not accurate at all.
The only families that will receive less under this program are families making over $70,000 a year and at the end of tax time there is virtually no difference for them anyway because the present family allowance is taxable. It is taxed back. The system that we are talking about now will be a non-taxable support package, one payment coming in monthly. It will allow families to manage their money better. There will be a flow of money coming in monthly versus getting family allowance on a monthly basis and having to wait until tax time to take advantage of the other parts of the program, whether it be the child tax credit or the refundable child tax credit. Let the Canadian people know that this program will help families.
I want to give some examples of what it will actually do. Again, this is outlined in our brochure. It uses an example here of Patricia and her children. Patricia is a single parent who works in a clothing store. It outlines exactly what this program will do for her and her children, a single parent with two children, one aged three and one aged eight, the wages of that family of one working parent of $19,000 a year with child care expenses of $1,500 a year.
Under the plan that exists now, Patricia receives a monthly family allowance cheque of $69.76 for a total of $837 a year for her two children, Andrew and Jane. She pays tax. Can you believe it? A wage earner of $19,000 pays tax on that little bit of money, although she says, which is accurate, she receives an equivalent to married credit of $915 for Jane and the regular child tax benefit of $71 for her son Andrew.
It says that in November 1992 Patricia receives a prepayment of the refundable child tax credit. The remaining $400 is paid after the tax refund is filed. Total annual benefits for Andrew and Jane are $1,925.
Under the new system, after the introduction of this in January, the single parent will receive a single monthly cheque of $211.67 versus that single monthly payment of $69.76. Under the new program the total annual benefit would reach $2,540.
Unlike the program we are presently under, the new child tax benefit will not be subject to tax. She will also retain the equivalent to married credit for that one child.
The annual assistance for this family, a single mother working with two children, will be up by $615. By my standards that is more, not less. So it is with all families in that category of under $70,000 per year.
Again, the fundamentals are correct. Do not let the opposition confuse the Canadian people as to what is happening. The new system will work. It will be much fairer for those people that need income.
The other interesting thing about this new program is that welfare recipients, for example, will not receive less than what they did under the old program. The member opposite just admitted yes, in fact they will get the same. The important thing to remember, and I stress this, is that low income families, the working poor, will receive more.
If you question why would that be, it is very simple. Giving people the initiative or an incentive to do it themselves has to do with self-esteem and respect. Most people that I speak to want that self-respect. They want to feel that they have done something to better themselves. They want governments to recognize that.
All the other safety nets will be there for people who, for whatever reason, do not work or cannot work. We have those systems, the existing federal or provincial programs. But where we have fallen down as governments, and I am talking both federally and provincially, is that we have not recognized the working poor. That is the one big advantage in this new program. For once, we are recognizing the working poor. Over all, I can support this new system and I think that all fair-minded Canadians will support this new system.

Mr. Speaker, I am resuming the speech that I had to interrupt for lunch. I would like to come back to the speech given by my colleague from the Progressive Conservative Party.

When he says that he can support this legislation he ignores something that we have been addressing throughout the entire debate this day and the last.
That is that it is fundamentally flawed because it shows a particular philosophical departure from those tenets which we have established as being central to a Canadian identity, a social identity, one that puts the individual citizen first and foremost as the object of all legislative initiatives.
This morning I said that we have a basic problem with this legislation. That problem is seen in the way it does not address the interest and the needs of those elements of society which are most vulnerable.
Even my colleague from the Conservative Party has noted that young children of single parent families, which by the way have the largest increase in numbers in terms of types of families we have in this country, and children from welfare families are the ones most prone to the difficulties that are imposed by the vagaries of our economy, our marketplace and our society.
We see that not only through the very short term. Immediate needs of food, shelter and clothing, needs that will not be satisfied by this legislation, needs which set the fashion, have been diminished because of the government and this minister's actions in the past when we have cut $3.5 billion from this kind of a program through a cap on CAP and other such programs.
Those children suffer in the immediate short term, but they suffer as well through some of the findings of the government which findings indicate that students from families that have been improperly nourished by financial means find themselves at a disadvantage in school. They are the children which are most likely not to succeed. They also represent the greatest portion of those who fall into that category of dropping out prior to achieving a high school diploma.
What happens? I closed off this morning's debate with the suggestion that if we do not pay now, we will pay much more later. The government does not seem to appreciate that its own findings suggest that not nourishing our society at this level today means that we will have a loss in productivity which it has identified with its studies. We will have a built-in clientele for large

unemployment as we head into a highly technological advanced period in the history of mankind. Most of all, we will create a clientele of dependency among those who are going to be very ill equipped to handle the new changes that come upon us.
Yet this government says that we must accept this legislation without any of the amendments that the opposition members who have so studiously laboured over this bill are putting forward.
When I say studiously laboured over in order to arrive at such amendments, I remind the Speaker and members of this House that only one witness that appeared before the committee studying this legislation had anything positive to say about the legislation, just one, a junior professor at one of the universities. what we can get for ourselves", rather than what we can do to enhance this country and to make it grow.

He says:
On visits home I see a nation tom apart by bitter squabbling over constitutional language issues largely focused on the "founding cultures" both of which have become fossilized, intransigent and practically oblivious to the fact that much of Canada's current vigour derives from neither its French nor its British roots. They do it under the disability pension for people in my province. You get the indexation one month and the next month the cheque goes down.
There is another thing I want to say and it is a shame. I wanted to say that our party feels there should be a child benefit adjustment board. There are those people who do suffer the loss of a job and have to wait for their next yearly income tax. There will be a transition there that is going to hurt families and children across the board.
The minister may want to rise and say that people can write in right away and do this and this. Does he know that I am getting pensions that are under the Canada disability plan that have been there for many years. They are getting $20,000 back and they have to pay the welfare back? The systems don't work any more in this government.
This government is a tired government. This government has got to go. It has lost the confidence of the Canadian people and this is just one more action to help I don't know who. It may help their election perhaps by bribing some Canadians until June next year.

Canadians know very well that first we dealt with the convention for children which was signed by the Prime Minister last December in front of all the children of Canada and is highly regarded by all Canadians.
Second, we announced the package of children's benefits which represents more than $2 billion over five years for the children of Canada. We are trying to help what we called at the time the low income workers' children, those who will not receive the benefits of the social benefit system but at the same time are within the $10,000 to $20,000 bracket.

At the same time, we announced in June-
Mr. Speaker, a point of order. The minister states that a woman will receive an extra $400, but the documents states $500. Would the minister please clarify whether it is $400 or $500.

speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
If the documents say $500, trust the documents, because the documents were prepared by the minister.
What I was about to say is that we also announced what we called at the time the Children at Risk: Brighter Futures with $500 million for children. It deals with the question of the promotion, the protection and the prevention of all problems that our children, particularly those who are between zero and seven years of age, face in the country. All of this represents more than $3 billion announced by this government for the children of Canada over the past six months.
I repeat what I said. It was highly applauded by Canadians. We know that 75 to 80 per cent of Canadians agreed, particularly with the children's benefit program. Canadians agreed that we should be giving more money to the poorer people, the poorer families and less to those with higher incomes who are more able to look after themselves and their children. That is the policy we are talking about.
The reason we asked the House to pass the bill today is so that we will be able to give that money to the children of Canada beginning January 1,1993. It is a good reason. We believe that it is a good policy.
The opposition should applaud it. I do not understand why they are opposed to us giving $1 billion more to the children of Canada. It is not the way they would do it. We are doing what we can within our capacity. We have to face fiscally and economically that reality, not in the way they did it before when they had exhausted almost all the capacity that this country had to pay not only for children.

Also, I think that Canadians in general are satisfied with the way the government has acted toward Canada's children, especially with the fact that in the past six months we added $3.1 billion to the money already paid. That was quite an effort, recognized throughout the

world, considering that the programs for children in Canada are now among the best in the world and still managed in a fiscally responsible way.
Again, when we look at all we are doing, of course, as we say for the constitutional agreement, it is not perfect and we are quite aware of that. But given our ability to face our actual situation today, we think that $3.1 billion, of which $2 billion will be allocated directly over five years to help low income working parents improve their revenue, is a matter of balance, whatever the New Democrats in particular think of the famous sacrosanct principle of universality whereby people earning $500,000 a year got family allowances when low-income individuals benefited less.
With that in mind, I hope and trust-
-the opposition will now applaud the quality of the bill, particularly because it is part of a package which has been announced over the last six months. We have, among the industrialized countries of the world, almost the best programs and we provide the best programs we can for the children of Canada.
Therefore, I would appreciate it if the opposition would recognize what this government has done. It may be the most that any Government of Canada has done for the children of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to take part in this debate and to support the amendments put forward by my hon. colleague from Winnipeg North Centre.
This amendment would permit the Minister of National Revenue to reassess the child benefit amount in the case of a loss of family income and make an adjustment within three months. This amendment would address the responsiveness problem in the bill which would result in an 18-month delay in adjusting the benefit.
Listening to the minister speak just a moment ago begs the question: If this legislation is going to be that great a benefit to the children of Canada, why did all of the groups, why did our critic in the Liberal Party and the other critics and the various groups across the country
appearing before the committee have a different opinion?
I fear that the Canada we have known in the social sense is about to come to an end. The legislation being debated marks the end of universality of one of the oldest social programs and, as far as I am concerned, is replacing it with a magic show full of smoke and mirrors and sleight of hand to make the poorest of Canadians feel that they are receiving some kind of a benefit just before the next election.
We have seen some remarkable displays from this government in the past. While it gears up for the next election, our mail boxes have been flooded with tabloid style advertising sheets, as we know, singing the praises of the free trade deal and promising even better results from NAFTA, lb read the propaganda being put forward, one would be hard-pressed to figure out why over
1.5	million Canadians are looking for work and why the country is in the depths of the worst economic downturn since another Prime Minister was going to blast his way into the markets of the world in the 1930s.
The legislation which is before us today is somewhat similar to the sheet being put out about how healthy our economy is. The legislation is part of a fundamental change in our social policy, designed to give the illusion of increased benefits beginning next January, reinforced at tax time by seemingly increased family benefits.
We know that the next federal election must be held before the end of November 1993, coincidentally about the same time the benefits which seem so real early in the year will start to disappear and the true nature of this legislation will become obvious. This legislation will then be seen for what it is, part of an agenda which is designed to further advance the interests of those that control the assets of this nation. The old saying "the rich get richer while the poor get poorer" has never been more true than when speaking of this legislation.
As I said before, almost every witness who appeared before the committee studying this legislation condemned it. Representatives from welfare groups and agencies, from family services groups and academics were virtually unanimous in their condemnation. It was said that the legislation would do nothing to reduce or eliminate childhood poverty, nor would it do anything to allow people to raise themselves up to a higher economic
