PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS	faced with a recession and a restructuring of the economy not only in Canada but world-wide. Some may not want to admit it but the fact is a lot of plants are closing [English]	here an(j vvhen they close here they move somewhere
else. We attribute that to the effects of the free trade EMPLOYEE SHARE PURCHASE PLAN ACT agreement with the United States.

The House resumed from Tliesday, June 9, consideration of the motion of Mr. Butland that Bill C-327, an act to assist employees to purchase a controlling shareholding in the corporation that employs them and to amend the Income Tax Act in consequence thereof, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Economics envelope.

Mr. Speaker, the House is faced with a private members' bill, Bill C-327. It stands in the name of my colleague, the member for Sault Ste. Marie. I think not only this House but all of Canada is indebted to my colleague for having put before this House a very creative and innovative proposal.
He is to be congratulated because in his own community he was faced with a very serious problem. Here is a member of Parliament representing a community in which the major industry employing some 5,000 or more people was faced with a shutdown.
This member of Parliament, along with the community, decided to work diligently to try and address that specific problem. Rather than spitting into the wind, rather than cursing the darkness, my colleague, the member for Sault Ste. Marie, decided to work diligently to find a solution to a problem that faced not only Algoma Steel but increasingly in 1992 faced many other communities.
We are in a period of recession and we have been in periods of recession before. I remember the recession of 1982 very well when plants were closing, when plants were laying people off in my own community. INCO and Falconbridge closed down for a whole year. The workers were laid off but hope sprang eternal in their breasts because they knew once the economy turned around they would be recalled and production would continue and they would earn wages and be able to pay then-expenses and keep their families.
It is very different in 1992. Invariably when the plants close today, hope does not spring eternal because we are
There is evidence of thousands of jobs being lost because the plants close here and relocate to the sunshine states where costs are less.
Plants do not have to worry about heating in the winter. In some cases there are no minimum wage laws in those states. The laws governing the organization of trade unions are very weak or non-existent, they are right to work states. They do not have effective legislation, not only on the books but enforced, with respect to occupational health and safety in the work place.
I was just listening to As It Happens last night. I heard about a chicken plant somewhere in Mississippi in which the conditions were most appalling. A fire took place in the plant and workers lost their lives.
As I said, in 1992 we are dealing with a different situation, not the same situation that existed in 1982. Plants are leaving now and not coming back. In some of these instances it is not that the plants are not making money, it is not that they are not making profits. In many instances it is that they are not making enough profits.
We have the case of Algoma. We have the case of Spruce Falls Pulp and Paper plant in Kapuskasing. It was going to close, not because it was not making money, but because it was not making enough money for those who owned the plant.
What my colleague has proposed is an employee ownership plan. At the moment we have no federal structure for employee ownership. It seems to me that federal governments, not only in the past but now the present government as well, deal with these situations in a knee-jerk reactionary approach. It is crisis management. As the crises arise, they tiy to come to a solution to the problem. Ontario and Manitoba are contemplating and have proposed legislation which sets a framework within which employee ownership can take place.
What my colleague has presented to the House of Commons is a bill, Bill C-327, which sets out the parameters and lays out the structure in which this type

of ownership can take place. Why is it needed federally? As my colleague has pointed out, there is a need for the federal agencies to be involved. It means that we are thinking of a whole new concept. We are making the capital markets available to workers. Presently, capital markets are available to corporations and very wealthy individuals. What we are attempting in this plan is to make those capital markets available to workers.
To do that we need the co-operation of Revenue Canada, for example. The plan my colleague has put forward requires that the incentives extended to corporations vis-a-vis the Income Tax Act on investments should also be available to workers.
Surely this has to be a positive thing for Canada. When a worker starts taking responsibility for his work place in terms of being an owner, that has to have an effect, not only in terms of decision making, not just on the plant floor, but all the way to the board room. That input is important to the overall productivity of the plant. The sense of ownership that comes with this kind of plan is an important incentive for a worker to feel like part of the operation, thereby resulting in greater productivity.
This is the most effective way of redistributing wealth within the country and maintaining Canadian ownership in the work place and the corporations of the country.
Presently there is no federal legislation on this matter. Quebec has been light years ahead of the federal government with its co-op legislation which allows a corporation to shift from being privately owned to a co-op.
There are solidarity funds that allow for shares to be purchased in companies. That is not the plan my colleague has put forward. His plan deals with the individual workers working together as part of a collective purchasing ownership in the corporation, actually owning assets and influencing decisions on the daily operations and on the over-all strategy of the plant.
As I said before, I want to commend my colleague for this initiative. It certainly brings to our attention a very creative and innovative way to approach the problem in which we find ourselves. The example I mentioned before in Kapuskasing where the workers' jobs were
Private Members' Business
saved because of an ownership plan and the Ontario government. This is probably one of the great achievements of the Ontario government. It saved the community that depended on that plant. I might point out that between December 1991 and June 1992 the plant turned a profit of $2 million.
I say to my colleague and to my colleagues in the House that Bill C-327 is the flagship of employee ownership in Canada. It is an idea whose time has come.

Mr. Speaker, we are considering today Bill C-327 which proposes a 50 per cent tax deduction for investments to finance employee takeovers of the businesses where they work.
This deduction would be available to employees, employers or financial institutions involved in such investments.
The proposal raises a number of questions which deserve our careful consideration. One should ask whether the proposal is good for employees, whether it is good for business and finally whether it is good for taxpayers as a group.
We have been fortunate enough to have this summer to ponder these questions. I have spent considerable time studying the issues involved and have come to the conclusion that on the whole this proposal raises more problems than it resolves.
However, I welcome the opportunity to share with hon. members the reasoning which brings me to this conclusion.
I would begin by examining the proposal from the employees' standpoint. None would deny that Canadian employees put forward a great deal of effort in order to bring home their pay cheques. Their cheques must cover their bills for food, shelter, clothing and transportation. If they have special needs, these too must be met with the same pay cheques. We certainly cannot overlook the amount that must be set aside for provincial, federal and municipal taxes.
On top of all these spending pressures, Canadian employees must do their best to provide for their future financial needs. Perhaps when faced with ill health or unemployment, and almost certainly with decreased earnings during retirement, employees must try to set

Private Members' Business
something aside and must decide where best to place the nest egg.
This is not an easy decision for any of us. We all have acquaintances who are willing to undertake what we would consider overly risky investments. They do so in the full knowledge that high rewards often accompany high risks. At the same time, we all know of those who invest with safety first considerations at the top of the agenda. They are prepared to take a somewhat lower return in exchange for the peace of mind that comes from safe investments.
Which is the best strategy? The answer to this apparently straightforward question is it depends. It depends on the individual making the decision. What is best is a very personal decision that is governed by a number of factors, including the individual's past experiences, current situation and outlook for the future. Should we, through the income tax system, be sending individuals signals telling them how to allocate their hard won saving? Is acquiring a controlling interest in one's employer company a desirable investment for everyone? Is it such a desirable investment that it warrants the government's seal of approval in the form of a 50 per cent tax deduction? I would be tempted to answer no to some of these questions. What concerns me particularly is the plan proposed in Bill C-327 which was designed for situations where the financial viability of the employer is in some doubt. Such turnaround situations constitute high risk investments, not bad investments necessarily, but certainly not one that everyone would make in the absence of a tax break.
It is not appropriate for the government to entice employees to place their savings in a particular investment by leaving the bait of an attractive tax break. We do not provide 50 per cent tax deductions for lottery tickets and for good reason. Many Canadians buy lottery tickets nonetheless. I wish them the best of luck. It is a lottery ticket buyer's own calculations and whims which lead to the purchase of a ticket, not the lure of tax deductions.
I am convinced that a good number of Canadians have found and will continue to find investments in their employers to be a good home for their savings. The tax system should by no means discourage such investments. My point is that the tax system should likewise avoid
tipping the balance in favour of a particularly risky type of investment. Bill C-321 would do just that.
I strongly believe that our tax system will serve employees in Canada best if it plays a neutral role with respect to investment decisions.
I mentioned at the outset of my remarks that we must also assess this proposal from the point of view of the businesses which would be affected. If this proposal is good for business, some would argue that it may be worthy of our support even if it is questionable from the perspective of the employee investors.
It is timely to ask this question because some fundamental assumptions underlying the traditional relationships between the owners, managers and employees of business are in the process of being re-examined.
Increased employee participation is cited by many analysts as the key to business success. These same analysts often suggest that it is crucial for employees and employers to recognize that they have a common interest in the success of the organization. One of the key devices identified for reinforcing this appreciation of common interest is a remuneration structure which enables employees to share in the successes of the enterprise.
In these discussions, employee ownership is sometimes cited as the answer to Canada's problem of productivity and competitiveness. If employees acquire control of the business where they work, they clearly are participating in the operation of the enterprise. If they own shares, the remuneration is clearly tied to the success of the business.
But employee ownership is not the only means for achieving such ends. Much has been written of late concerning the success achieved by quality circles and other approaches to involving employees more fully in operational decisions. These techniques work and they do not involve employee ownership. Many firms offer profit-sharing plans or tie a portion of pay to the individual, department or enterprise performance. These techniques too are effective and they do not involve employee ownership.
Increasingly, firms are encouraging employees to acquire shares in the business. This technique achieves its goal without requiring employees to take a controlling position.


By citing these examples of different approaches to increasing employee involvement and thereby enterprise success, I merely wish to point out that the mechanism described in Bill C-327 is but one of many means to the same end. The fact that these other means are being used and are meeting with success and that they are doing so without tax assistance is important I believe.
Businesses and employees are re-examining their traditional relationships and are changing them. Different approaches seem to work best in different situations, but providing tax assistance for one approach and not for others may well discourage the very process we wish to promote, that is, establishing employee-employer co-operation in the fashion which best suits the particular situation and thereby achieving higher productivity and greater prosperity.
Bill C-327 might inadvertently place a strait-jacket on a dynamic, innovative search that is now going on in Canada to find a better way of doing things.
We all wish to ensure that the best business decisions are reached. When a business thrives Canadians benefit as employees, customers, suppliers, shareholders and simply by participating in a prosperous economy.
We should all agree therefore to avoid using our tax system in a manner that would lead to sub-optimal business decisions in the important field of employee-employer relations. A level tax-playing field is essential if we are interested in business success. This bill unfortunately would tilt the field.
I have talked at some length on the implications of this proposal for the employees and businesses involved. Let me now take a broader perspective and consider what is best for the taxpayers of Canada. There is no denying that a 50 per cent tax has a certain appeal if you belong to the select group that is to benefit from it. That is the employees of target companies and others who help finance the takeover. What if you are not fortunate enough to be in that group?
Most Canadians would not benefit from the provisions of this proposal. It excludes Canadians who are outside of the labour force, who are unemployed, self-employed or employed in the non-corporate sector. It excludes Canadians who lack the means of a desire to invest in
Private Members' Business
their employers. It excludes most of us if those excluded would have to provide the extra taxes required to pay for this new tax deduction. Therefore, it is difficult to support the idea of asking a large majority of Canadians to pay higher taxes so that a select few can benefit from a 50 per cent tax deduction.
I hope I have made the position clear that I do not support this measure because it fails on the counts I have illustrated. It is not particularly or necessarily good for the employees. It is not necessarily good for business and it is not necessarily good for Canadian taxpayers. However, I think the member should be commended for bringing forward this proposal for discussion to be considered because at a time like this when we are going through difficult economic times, we want to look at all aspects in any proposals that may have appeal. I do not say that his proposal is without merit. I just wanted to highlight some of the things that you could take into consideration very carefully when it comes time to decide the fate of this proposal.

Mr. Speaker, I, too, wish to participate in this private members' bill, Bill C-327, an act to assist employees to purchase a controlling shareholding in the corporation that employs them and to amend the Income Tax Act in consequence thereof.
I commend the member for Sault Ste. Marie for putting forward this private members' bill. I think he has shown a great deal of initiative. He has experienced the problem within his own area with regard to Algoma Steel, the problems that it faced and the procedures it had to follow.
I want to comment a little bit on what is happening in my riding of Kootenay East where Westar has gone into bankruptcy. It went into a bankruptcy situation on May 3. Not only was it going into bankruptcy, but it decided it was not going to pay the holiday pay or the severance pay, so it locked out its employees. That initially stopped the employee-workers of that mine from participating in the judge's comments, decision and procedures of the bankruptcy. The employees, 1,100 of them in a one-industry town, did not have the opportunity to participate in the bankruptcy decisions because they were locked out. They were unable to get unemployment insurance. This went on for four months.

Private Members' Business
During that bankruptcy discussion in the banks under the Creditors Arrangement Act, the creditors, the company, provincial governments and the various financial institutions had opportunities to discuss the bankruptcies. There is no mechanism in place for the employees to participate or to bring about the kind of a program such as the member for Sault Ste. Marie has put forward.
The bankruptcy took place on August 25. The court decided it had until September 26, a little over a month, at which time liquidation could start to take place. This is a profitable mine. This mine has second and third generation employees in a single-industiy town. It has been profitable. It has long-lasting contracts with the Japanese markets. This is a veiy profitable mine. It has been admitted by the governments, the creditors and various others that it is a profitable mine. The employees wish to participate with a new buyer to tiy to bring about solutions, but I want to say they have until September 26. If liquidation starts to take place and some of that machinery starts to come out of that mine and is liquidated, what is the chance of that mine ever starting up again?
Here is an opportunity for a piece of legislation. The Americans have it in place.
I hate to use the American scheme as a project. The Japanese have employee contributions and employee programs in which they can participate. The United States has had legislation for 20 years that facilitates employee ownership. In fact almost one quarter of all American steel workers are involved in an employee share plan.
While I am speaking here in the House, those 11,000 workers and their representatives are meeting with a new buyer. They are pleading with me: Is there any federal help that can help us with regard to taxation benefits or some other types of benefits? I have had to tell them sadly there is not.
My colleague, the member for Sault Ste. Marie, has put forward a piece of legislation that could facilitate that kind of thing. I heard the comments and the rattle that was made by one of the members from the government side, but I would urge the government to take a serious look at this piece of legislation.
Surely to goodness if that legislation is put in place the government in power can look at the feasibility along
with the provincial governments, the community involved, and the workers involved. We are talking about a one-industry town that has been in this industry for over 100 years. There are second and third generations that have paid taxes to the Canadian public provincially and federally throughout these years. They were participating.
They know it is a profitable mine. It can contribute. It can continue. The markets are even there. The will must come from the governments. These workers are even prepared to participate in an employee-share benefit with new employers or with themselves if they have to.
All they are asking for is the same type of relief, the same kind of support that business gets when it wants to get into that kind of a situation. The very part that bothers me so much about it is that less than 10 years ago, I stood in this House when the Liberals were in government. They were putting as much as $1.5 billion into the development of northeast coal in direct conflict with southeast coal.
Now we come to a situation where southeast coal is in a financial problem and needs some assistance, whether it be through this type of legislation, whether it be direct participation between the federal and provincial governments, and the municipalities, and we are told that the employees are not smart enough to be able to participate in this kind of a structure.
I want to protect these employees. The member on the government side said: "We would like to protect these employees from destroying themselves". I want to say to him that those employees do not need protection. Those United Mine Workers and their representatives have been to Japan. They have met with the steel companies in Japan.
They have looked at the operations of the mines in Russia and in Japan where the markets are. They know that this is a viable mine. This is a mine that should be working. It should not be into bankruptcy. It was a planned bankruptcy. There is no question about it. Westar went to the banks less than two years ago and tried a restructuring and a refinancing of its companies. It separated west coast terminals.
Imagine the banks with $300 million of loans into this Westar Mining company coming back for a restructuring and saying: "We are going to take the west coast

terminals out of our proposal and we will put the rest up for security".
It was planned two years ago when it took its west coast terminals out and protected that portion of it. The profits from that mine, which is the Balmer Mine in Sparwood, belong to Westar. Westar was into many other types of facilities such as pulp mills, off-shore drilling, lumber mills. The profits from this very viable mine were going in all directions and not being put back into the mine.
The piece of legislation that the member from Sault Ste. Marie has put forward is one that this government should look at very, very seriously. The Japanese have allowed it and the Americans have put it in. If we are going to be into free trade agreements with other areas, let our people at least have the same kind of legislation here so they can benefit and try to bring it about. It is going to have to be in place so that workers and companies can use it.
September 26 will come along and if they have not found a solution to this situation in the Balmer Mine, then liquidation could take place and the chances of ever bringing that mine back on stream are probably going to be very, very limited.

Mr. Speaker, it is quite obvious to most of us why the member for Sault Ste. Marie brought this Bill C-327 forward. I do not think too many of us would argue on the merits of why he wanted to do that. Obviously, that part of our country which is his riding is going through a very, very difficult time and they are looking for a solution to a problem. We have to give the member full credit for attempting to do something.
I will be addressing this bill from an economic point of view and from a tax revenue point of view It is a bill that is certainly worthy of debate. It is not a frivolous bill and it is one that we take very seriously.
When this government took office in 1984 that was one of the things we looked at as a government in terms of how we tax. We wanted to bring certain things into the taxation system that we thought were missing at the time. One was, of course, the ability of individuals to pay
Private Members' Business
taxes. We wanted a system that was fair. We worked to achieve that. Another thing we took a look at was the plugging of loopholes.
The members opposite me, such as the member for Sault Ste. Marie and his counterpart who just spoke, have often been on their feet in this House of Commons suggesting ways in which we can plug those loopholes. Through Standing Order 31 they are famous for delivering the corporate welfare bum award of the week. They do it on occasion with a great deal of drama attached to it. Often, although I hate to admit it, they are absolutely right in some of their presentations. We have committed ourselves to plugging some of those loopholes which have been identified by their party. In doing that we are eliminating preferred tax treatment for some Canadians. That is something we are all sensitive to in the sense that we give tax breaks to certain Canadians, whether they are rich Canadians or corporate Canadians.
We have made a great effort to reduce those preferred tax incentives. In doing some of those things we have passed on those savings to individual Canadians in the form of lower personal taxes. Obviously, when we try to change the system again and move in the direction of Bill C-327, we have to be cognizant of the fact that there is going to be some revenue foregone and given up by the Government of Canada. We are not talking about a little bit of money, we are talking about a lot of money. It is millions and millions of dollars.
If you forego that revenue the question then becomes: "From what other source can we get it?" The only other source is the Canadian taxpayer. Therefore, we want a system that does not discriminate against individual Canadians. In a sense, Bill C-327 does that and I will go through the reasons why.
Let us take a careful look at the bill itself and exactly what it does. The purpose of the bill is to use federal funds delivered through generous tax deductions to encourage employees to take over corporations that employ them. Specifically it proposes to amend the Income Tax Act to provide a 50 per cent deduction from taxable income for employee and employer investments in tax vehicles known as employee share purchase plans, or ESPPs. It also proposes to give a tax break to banks and other financial institutions that would take part in these plans.

Adjournment Debate
It runs somewhat contrary to the position of the party to which the member for Sault Ste. Marie belongs. I believe that the party to which he belongs is fundamentally opposed to creating tax breaks for banks and other financial institutions. That is exactly what it does.
In a case like his-and I guess this is where politics comes in. I am not arguing against what he is saying in a personal sense because, believe me, if that situation existed in my constituency I would be doing the same thing, although in this case it philosophically flies in the face of the party that he represents. Indeed, it would give a tax break to financial institutions, obviously including banks. I think that runs against the grain of most Canadians at this time, particularly at a time when bank profits are at an all-time high. We have been reminded in this House, particularly by those on the other side, how high those profits were. So I do not think that any of us want to see tax breaks for banks and financial institutions at this point.
I have mentioned the redistribution aspect. If revenue is lost from one source it must be made up from another source, and unfortunately that other source always comes down to the individual taxpayer.
The other aspect that we should take a look at is what we do, in terms of investment, to encourage individuals to invest in Canada. We do that at present and we do it in a number of ways. One of those ways is to tax investment income differently than earned income in the work force. One of those methods I am referring to is dividend income. It is taxed differently to encourage those Canadians who desire to invest in a corporation to do so. Dividends are taxed differently than simple interest income.
In other words, it is an incentive for people like ourselves to not just place money in stale bank accounts but to invest in Canadian corporations. When we do that we are given a little bit of a tax break. I do not think the tax break at this point is as lucrative as it should be or could be. In fact we have changed that law from time to time with the sense that it was maybe too lucrative.
That is one type of investment break for Canadians. The other one is the capital gains tax. Individual Canadians are allowed $100,000 in capital gains income before they are taxed. That simply means that if an individual has a choice to make in terms of what they want to do
with their money, if they take a look at investing that money in stock or in a Canadian corporation in terms of achieving some capital gains on that investment they are going to be given a break, a $100,000 break.
That has been attacked again by the NDP and by the Liberal governments. They suggest that it is perhaps too lucrative. That $100,000 exemption is extended to $500,000 for investing in small Canadian corporations, because those are the corporations that need the funding and the capital. We have done that as a government, as well.
The point of the exercise is that we have a number of instruments out there at present that allow Canadians to invest in Canadian companies for the right reasons. Through the retirement funds, Registered Retirement Savings Plans, individuals can invest in companies they work for. They then receive a 100 per cent tax break on the dollars they invest in that corporation. The belief is that we invest now when we are working and can contribute and later on when we retire we can draw that money back out at a lower rate of taxation. That instrument is also readily available for employees who presently want to do that.
We could go through a raft of other vehicles that are available at this present time without having to move in the direction of Bill C-327.

Mr. Speaker, according to the National Judicial Institute 40 per cent of all federal and provincial judges have not taken advantage of the gender sensitization courses available to them.
The report of the Law Society of British Columbia's gender bias committee has concluded that gender inequality is pervasive in the legal and justice systems in B.C.
September 15, 1992

The committee also recognized that significant steps must be taken by all the actors involved-the government, the judiciary, the legal profession, and other service providers in the justice system-in order to eliminate such bias and to uphold Canadians' perception that their justice system is and at least can be a model of fairness.
For example, the study found that while judges are becoming more aware of gender bias some nonetheless continue to exhibit a lack of sensitivity toward victims of wife assault and sexual assault. There is also evidence that suggests that women are regarded as less credible witnesses than men and that stereotypical notions about women undermine the prosecution of such assault cases.
It is obvious from the above finding that voluntary gender sensitization only preaches to the already converted. Those judges who belittle the suffering of women at the hands of their spouses are those most in need of such courses, yet they are the ones who feel that training is not necessary.
The committee concluded that the existence of direct and systemic biases in the courtroom, the legal profession, and other areas requires that each sector of the justice system critically examine its role in perpetuating gender inequality. This could be accomplished if those who work in the system were educated about gender bias in their own beliefs and in the laws and how they are applied.
The recommendations are wide-ranging and include judicial education courses in family law, addressing spousal maintenance, and accurate information about the costs of child raising. Spousal maintenance is all too often insufficient, as anyone who has practised family law knows, because the courts underestimate the economic disadvantages borne primarily by women as a result of child rearing.
The second recommendation is regular training for judges by the Canadian Justice Institute designed to make them aware of the subtle and overt manifestations of gender bias directed toward women lawyers, witnesses, and litigants. Another recommendation is training for family court counsellors that includes a gender equity component. This training program should parallel the training received by judges and masters.
The final recommendation is judicial education programs providing information on how sex-based stereo-
Adjoumment Debate
types about women and men affect decision-making in custody cases.
I could go on but there was a commercial once that talked about what happened if you did not fix your car. The mechanic said: "You can pay me now or you can pay me later". How much more relevant is this theory when we are talking about human lives. We can pay now to make judges and the judicial system more sensitive and the ramifications for families will be far better in the long run, or we can pay later in the broken lives that such decisions will engender.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I agree that gender equality is an objective and should be sought in our justice system. No one, male or female, should be in any doubt that he or she will be treated fairly and with dignity in our courts of law and other institutions of justice.
To this end ministers of justice and attorneys general have adopted a statement of principles aimed at ensuring equality of treatment in the Canadian system of justice, with special efforts being made to accommodate the needs of indigenous people and women from multicultural communities.
The judiciary has also recognized a need to address equality issues. The National Judicial Institute and the Western Judicial Education Centre, Canada's two leading institutions for judicial education, have created programs on gender issues at the request of judges themselves. These programs have been highly effective and well received. On the basis of their experience with these programs, both institutions have decided that all future judicial education programming will include components that place gender issues in context within the treatment of substantive law subjects.
There is some concern, however, that unprecedented attacks have been made upon the fairness and integrity of persons who have a very difficult and important job and who do extremely well. Isolated incidents have been seized upon as being indicative of the attitude of all judges, whether federally or provincially appointed, male or female. Individual judges have been tried in the public press on the basis of statements which have been taken out of context or sometimes misconstrued. Respective careers have been shattered and additional pressures added to the heavy burden of responsibility on the

Adjournment Debate
judiciaries' already heavily-laden shoulders. A new disincentive may be added to the acceptance of judicial office.
Under these circumstances, in which the judiciary and governments are dealing effectively with gender equality issues, we should be aware of warnings issued by educators in the United States which suggest that mandatory gender sensitization training can be counter-productive and can undermine all of the good work that has been done so far. Certainly we should take an informed interest in judicial education, but equally we should trust to the good faith and good will of the men and women of the judiciary who have thus far shown themselves more than worthy of the confidence of their fellow Canadians.

Mr.Speaker, my particular constituency, Don Valley East, takes its name from the Don River. When I was a kid we used to swim in the Don River but no one would swim in it today. It is polluted with raw sewage and industrial waste.
Also according to the Great Lakes Science Advisory Board's report to the International Joint Commission, the Don River is polluted with toxic materials carried through the atmosphere from Latin America. According to the board's study 70 per cent of the lead in Lake Ontario, 80 per cent of the PCBs in Lake Erie, 90 per cent of the PCBs in Lake Superior, all travel through the atmosphere from Latin America thousands of miles away to pollute our Great Lakes.
Therefore, even if we clean up our own act, the Great Lakes and the Don River are still going to be polluted. The source of the pollution, according to this study, is some 11,000 tonnes of DDT used each year in Latin America.
One of those Latin American countries is Mexico and we just initialled a free trade agreement with Mexico, NAFTA. One of the things that concerns a great many Canadians about NAFTA is the environmental standards in Mexico.
Our government has told us not to worry about that because Mexico has good environmental laws, it just does not enforce them. It also tells us not to worry about that either because we have just provided Mexico with $1 million to help it enforce those good environmental laws,
even though Mexico is not one of those countries that qualifies for this sort of assistance under the Canadian International Development Agency under normal circumstances. We also should not worry because we have an environmental co-operation agreement with Mexico that we signed back in 1990 and so everything is going to be all right.
Now that Mexico is enforcing its really strict environmental laws using Canadian money, I want to ask the parliamentary secretary tonight if he will give me and all Canadians answers to the following questions. First of all, when can we expect Mexico to stop using DDT? Second, if it does not stop using it immediately, can we use the dispute settlement mechanism in NAFTA to require it to stop? And third, when can I and my constituents start swimming in the Don River again?

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am afraid I cannot, in all honesty, answer the last of my hon. friend's three questions because, as he knows, the clean-up of already polluted bodies of water is an extremely difficult and costly procedure.
Having said that, the important point is to ensure that we and other residents of North and South America work together to address international pollution problems as we are doing at the present time.
The hon. friend made reference to NAFTA. One of the key points about the NAFTA agreement is that it is the first time we have had such an assessment in a trade agreement. There is an environment assessment in the agreement itself and that will be made available to the public at the same time at which the legal text is made available.
I can also inform my hon. friend that later this very week, the Minister of the Environment from Canada will be meeting with his Mexican and American counterparts in Washington to talk about the way in which the three governments, the three ministers of the environment and their officials, can work together to make sure that common environmental problems are addressed effectively. I would anticipate that what will come out of the meeting is the establishment of some sort of trilateral
September 15, 1992

panel and the objective will be to address the very concerns which my hon. friend is raising.

Mr. Speaker, on April 8, 1992, I asked the Acting Prime Minister a question. It went something like this: Since the government had said that henceforth the provinces and territories would finance cases concerning language rights and equality rights, did the government consult the provinces and territories? Here is the answer that the Deputy Prime Minister gave me: This program could be funded by the private sector or by the provinces.
Of course, without meaning badly, it did not consult. It hoped that the provinces, territories and private sector would come to the defence of these groups, not only linguistic minorities but the other groups protected by this program. He did not really answer the question and that is why I am here this evening.
Mr. Speaker, I also want to point out that there is now a new constitutional reality, containing new provisions, as we very well know. I want to emphasize that this program ends on September 30. Given these new realities and that the government did not consult the provinces to see whether they were prepared to continue the work, is the government now ready to resume, restore and reinstate the Court Challenges Program?
Mr. Speaker, I feel that you must know that the Committee on Humam Rights and the Status of Disabled Persons unanimously recommended-that is, with the consent of the representatives from the three main parties-to continue it in one form or another. So it is really time to do something.
This committee said that the program was essential. It is even more essential today than it was when it was cut. I believe that it should be continued. I will give you two brief examples: the disabled are unhappy with the constitutional proposals; they will no doubt have demands to make, but who will be able to help them? Women, especially a certain women's group, are not at all happy and they too will no doubt want to challenge it.
The last example: you certainly know that the Frenchspeaking linguistic minorities, and maybe even the En-
Adjoumment Debate
glish-speaking, are debating the issue of "attachment" versus "commitment". I would prefer commitment, it is so clear. Jurists recognize it as a term with legal validity. Those are some questions that will have to be answered about this new constitutional reality.
So I ask the government to face up to its responsibilities.

speakeroldname: Mr. Charles A. Langlois (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Industry, Science and Technology):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my colleague from St. Boniface will certainly remember that the Court Challenges Program was set up by the federal government in 1978 to guarantee equality for linguistic minorities throughout the country.
In 1982 and again in 1985, the Court Challenges Program was extended to include the language rights and equality rights protected by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. Since 1978, the Court Challenges Program has been financed solely by the federal government. Therefore, Mr. Speaker, we did not consult our provincial colleagues about a decision affecting the federal budget.
The Court Challenges Program has proven useful in several important legal decisions that helped to clarify the Charter. In fact, many cases dealing with official languages and funded by the program have had a direct impact on the development and amendment of provincial legislation convering education in the official languages and linguistic minorities. The provinces were also influenced by the cases concerning equality heard by the courts. However, in a period of financial and economic difficulties and budget cuts, the government had to make some hard decisions. The Court Challenges Program was one of the programs that we had to abolish to achieve the objectives.
Mr. Speaker, in June, the Standing Committee on Human Rights and the Status of Disabled Persons tabled its report, "Paying Too Dearly", on the Court Challenges Program. The government is now considering this committee's report and will table its response to the recommendations in the House.
The government will continue to promote the right to equality for all citizens as it has committed itself to do. It also remains determined to promote the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms in every possible way.

September 15, 1992
Adjournment Debate

Mr. Speaker, the subject matter is employment or the lack of it in this country.
On April 29, 1992 I informed the minister of employment that a comprehensive economic review of the Hamilton labour market released at McMaster University concluded that while 36 per cent of employees felt they would be laid off this year, an astounding 52 per cent of business owners and managers said they will be laying off employees this year.
Given that alarming fact, I asked the minister what concrete action he will take to ensure that employees in Hamilton and in other great cities across this great country will not become statistics? It is called Question Period, after all, and seldom if ever do we in the loyal opposition get any answers from a government in which Canadians have lost faith.
In the city of Hamilton the unemployment rate has hovered over 10 per cent for close to two years. Last month it was again at close to 11 per cent. Hamiltonians are coming to my constituency office demanding to know why they are losing the opportunity to re-enter the job market because their unemployment insurance benefits will run out before the completion of their job retraining courses.
That very question was asked again today of the minister of employment by my colleague, the member for Parkdale-High Park. He appealed to the minister to extend UI benefits where necessary. By skirting that direct question, the minister who represents this sorry government might as well have cut his answer to the quick and simply said no, the government will not extend UI benefits to those in need.
Speaking of jobs and the lack of, the government spends literally millions of taxpayers' dollars on a propaganda paper extolling the virtues of the North American free trade deal. Who will lose their jobs because of the deal? How many will need help? What programs will those working men and women displaced by NAFTA attain?
Permit me to quote from today's editorial in a Toronto newspaper. First it speaks briefly about how U.S. Labour Secretary Lynn Martin said outright that the Canada-
U.S.-Mexico deal could cost up to 150,000 American jobs and that they were prepared to spend $750 million a year for five years to help workers who lose their jobs because of this NAFTA deal.
The editorial states:
In Canada, the Tbries have refused to help the victims of free trade, despite Brian Mulroney's 1988 election promise to provide "the finest programs anywhere". Since Ottawa still refuses to help those who suffer under free trade, it continues to pretend that they don't exist. And in trying to maintain that dishonest posture, it is indulging in propaganda warfare with Canadians.
I have said it before and I will say it again: Canadian workers are not looking for a handout. Canadian workers want a helping hand. Canadian workers want jobs, not welfare.

Mr. Speaker, as you know very well, a vital part of job creation is retraining of those who require it in order to find their place in the work force.
I am pleased to be able to inform you, Mr. Speaker, and through you, Canadians, that indeed we are spending record amounts on such job, training at the moment. This is a very substantial increase over moneys made available in the past, including as recently as some two years ago.
For example, we are spending this year a record $1.95 billion to train 300,000 UI claimants. That is three times what was spent in the same area in 1990. In addition, we will spend $1.6 billion in skills training and employment assistance for unemployed Canadians this year.
This brings total employment and training assistance for Canadians in 1992 to $3.55 billion. That is $3.55 billion, not million. Close to 700,000 Canadians will get some help this year from EIC training and adjustment programs.
In a slightly different vein, I would also like to note that last year 190,000 UI claimants received training under section 26 of which 39,000 were fee payers. This year, it is expected that about 300,000, a substantial increase of UI claimants, will receive training under section 96 and 85,000 of these will be fee payers.
That is an increase of some 46,000 fee payers over the last year. The need is great, but I would also point out in response to my hon. friend that a financial commitment of some $3.55 billion to provide training to 700,000 Canadians this year is also a very, very significant contribution.
